revision.comment: Add: year, isbn, pmid, author pars. 1-1. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[User:Josve05a|Josve05a]]
revision.text:
'''Morphokinetics ''('''''<nowiki/>''‘morpho’’'' form/shape<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/morpho-|title=morpho- - Wiktionary|website=en.wiktionary.org|language=en|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref> ''and ‘kinetics’'' movement<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/-kinetic|title=-kinetic|work=TheFreeDictionary.com|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref>) refers to time specific morphological changes during embryo development providing dynamic information on a fertilized egg. The detailed information eases morphological selection of embryos with high implantation potential to be used in [[In vitro fertilisation|In-Vitro Fertilisation]] treatment.
== Technology == The traditional method for selection of embryos to be used for embryo transfer in fertility treatments such as IVF, involves assessing the [[Morphology (biology)|morphology]] of a fertilized egg at crucial time points under a microscope.
The incorporation of [[Time-lapse embryo imaging|time lapse imaging]] tools in an incubator is a novel technology that allows images of embryo development to be captured frequently.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pirkevi Çetinkaya|first=Caroline|last2=Kahraman|first2=Semra|date=2016-08-09|title=Morphokinetics of embryos—where are we now?|journal=Journal of Reproductive Biotechnology and Fertility|language=en|volume=5|pages=205891581666385|doi=10.1177/2058915816663858|issn=2058-9158}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Basile|first=Natalia|last2=Caiazzo|first2=Mauro|last3=Meseguer|first3=Marcos|date=June 2015|title=What does morphokinetics add to embryo selection and in-vitro fertilization outcomes?|journal=Current Opinion in Obstetrics & Gynecology|volume=27|issue=3|pages=193–200|doi=10.1097/GCO.0000000000000166|issn=1473-656X|pmid=25699478}}</ref>
This together with softwares<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Aparicio-Ruiz|first=Belén|last2=Romany|first2=Laura|last3=Meseguer|first3=Marcos|date=2018-05-01|title=Selection of preimplantation embryos using time-lapse microscopy in in vitro fertilization: State of the technology and future directions|journal=Birth Defects Research|language=en|volume=110|issue=8|pages=648–653|doi=10.1002/bdr2.1226|pmid=29714056|issn=2472-1727}}</ref> allows embryologists and clinicans to interpret the embryo development information captured and select embryos for transfer in IVF treatment.
Research <ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Milewski|first=Robert|last2=Ajduk|first2=Anna|date=July 2017|title=Time-lapse imaging of cleavage divisions in embryo quality assessment|url=https://rep.bioscientifica.com/view/journals/rep/154/2/REP-17-0004.xml|journal=Reproduction|language=en-US|volume=154|issue=2|pages=R37–R53|doi=10.1530/REP-17-0004|pmid=28408705|issn=1470-1626|via=}}</ref> for an [[algorithm]] to select a single embryo that would lead to the best clinical pregnancy outcome is underway.
== Morphology == '''[[Morphology (biology)|Morphology]]''' of the [[embryo]] is studied in scientific research and often marked by stages. [[File:Stages of Morphology .png|thumb|437x437px|A flow chart summarizing the stages in morphology of the embryo.]] ''For further details of the processes that occur within each stage, see [[Human embryogenesis]].''
'''1. [[Fertilisation|Fertilization]]'''
After the egg is fertilized by the sperm, a [[zygote]] (single diploid cell) is formed. At this stage, it should have two [[Pronucleus|pronuclei]], one of each derived from the egg and the sperm cell respectively and two tiny cells called [[Polar body|polar bodies]].
'''2. [[Cleavage (embryo)|Cleavage]]'''
This begins when the zygote divides into two cells via [[mitosis]]. The division continues such that each cell divides into another two cells, which results in a multiplying effect.
'''3. [[Morula]]'''
The ball of cells formed after the multiple divisions is called a [[morula]]. It consists of about 16-32 cells in a ball within a translucent, elastic layer called the [[zona pellucida]]. It will then undergo compaction which is a process where the cells bind firmly together and continue to develop into a blastocyst. <ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j7GfgRIgP9YC&pg=PT233|title=How New Humans Are Made|isbn=9789812835147|last1=Boklage|first1=Charles E.|year=2010}}</ref>
'''4. [[Blastocyst]]'''
[[Blastula|Blastulation]] is marked by the appearance of a fluid-filled cavity ([[blastocoel]]) surrounded by a single layer of cells called the [[Trophoblast|trophectoderm]] and the [[inner cell mass]]. The fetus is developed from the inner cell mass while the placenta is derived from the trophectoderm. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kaser|first=Daniel J.|last2=Racowsky|first2=Catherine|date=2014-06-02|title=Clinical outcomes following selection of human preimplantation embryos with time-lapse monitoring: a systematic review|journal=Human Reproduction Update|language=en|volume=20|issue=5|pages=617–631|doi=10.1093/humupd/dmu023|pmid=24890606|issn=1355-4786}}</ref>
<gallery widths="250" heights="200"> File:Zygote1.jpg|Zygote File:Human Embryo.png|Cleavage Stage Embryo File:Blastocyst English.svg|Blastocyst </gallery>
== Benefits == Morphokinetics has the potential advantage over standard morphological evaluation as it does not use a static form of observation to evaluate a highly dynamic process<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Aparicio-Ruiz|first=Belén|last2=Romany|first2=Laura|last3=Meseguer|first3=Marcos|date=2018-05-01|title=Selection of preimplantation embryos using time-lapse microscopy in in vitro fertilization: State of the technology and future directions|journal=Birth Defects Research|language=en|volume=110|issue=8|pages=648–653|doi=10.1002/bdr2.1226|pmid=29714056|issn=2472-1727}}</ref>.
High resolution images obtained at frequent time points provides greater detail of the events involved in embryo development<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Aparicio|first=B.|last2=Cruz|first2=M.|last3=Meseguer|first3=M.|date=December 2013|title=Is morphokinetic analysis the answer?|journal=Reproductive BioMedicine Online|volume=27|issue=6|pages=654–663|doi=10.1016/j.rbmo.2013.07.017|pmid=24135156|issn=1472-6483}}</ref>. This higher degree of detail and parameters used to assess embryo viability reduces the biased variability in embryo selection by an embryologist, allowing for a more standardised method of embryo quality evaluation and selection for implantation<ref name=":1" />. This also provides a quantifiable method for analysis rather than just qualitative<ref name=":0" />.
Clinicians are given more time to evaluate an image rather than a time pressured evaluation of an embryo which must be quickly put back into incubation; resulting in a reduced degree of human error<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Herrero|first=Javier|last2=Meseguer|first2=Marcos|date=March 2013|title=Selection of high potential embryos using time-lapse imaging: the era of morphokinetics|journal=Fertility and Sterility|volume=99|issue=4|pages=1030–1034|doi=10.1016/j.fertnstert.2013.01.089|pmid=23395415|issn=0015-0282}}</ref>.
Potential damage to otherwise viable embryos is also reduced due to minimized fluctuation of optimal culture conditions . These factors such as pH and temperature, if altered, have been shown to influence preimplantation development of a blastocyst<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Paulson|first=Richard J.|last2=Reichman|first2=David E.|last3=Zaninovic|first3=Nikica|last4=Goodman|first4=Linnea R.|last5=Racowsky|first5=Catherine|date=April 2018|title=Time-lapse imaging: clearly useful to both laboratory personnel and patient outcomes versus just because we can doesn't mean we should|journal=Fertility and Sterility|volume=109|issue=4|pages=584–591|doi=10.1016/j.fertnstert.2018.01.042|pmid=29653705|issn=0015-0282}}</ref>.
Both the mother and child may benefit from this new method of IVF treatment. Transfer of the single, highest potential embryo into the mother reduces the likelihood of multiple gestations, which limits future complications such as preterm labour<ref name=":2" />.
This method reduces time spent and consequently lowering overall costs<ref name=":3" />.
Greater understanding and evidence for embryo morphokinetics can help improve current knowledge of embryo development and factors influencing successful clinical pregnancy outcome<ref name=":0" />.
== Limitations == Although morphokinetics has its advantage in terms of selecting embryos for implantation, the technology is unable to deselect all abnormal embryos.
There is also a struggle to find a universal algorithm as attempts to validate published algorithms have proved unsuccessful. More work needs to be done in the scientific community, working as a cohesive unit to define the best possible algorithm that could lead to a single successful pregnancy.<ref name=":4" />
The benefits of using morphokinetics in terms of improving clinical outcomes of IVF is still very unclear'''.'''<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kaser|first=Daniel J.|last2=Racowsky|first2=Catherine|date=2014-06-02|title=Clinical outcomes following selection of human preimplantation embryos with time-lapse monitoring: a systematic review|journal=Human Reproduction Update|language=en|volume=20|issue=5|pages=617–631|doi=10.1093/humupd/dmu023|pmid=24890606|issn=1355-4786}}</ref> A meta-analysis published in 2017, supported the idea of clinical benefits of time-lapse culture with morphokinetic embryo selection in IVF, reporting reduced early pregnancy loss, higher ongoing pregnancy and higher live birth rates. <ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Pribenszky|first=Csaba|last2=Nilselid|first2=Anna-Maria|last3=Montag|first3=Markus|date=November 2017|title=Time-lapse culture with morphokinetic embryo selection improves pregnancy and live birth chances and reduces early pregnancy loss: a meta-analysis|journal=Reproductive BioMedicine Online|volume=35|issue=5|pages=511–520|doi=10.1016/j.rbmo.2017.06.022|pmid=28736152|issn=1472-6483}}</ref>However, the studies included in the meta analysis were carried out in selected populations and were of dubious quality, meaning we can not rely on this as conclusive evidence that IVF outcomes are improved by using morphokinetic embryo selection and time-lapse technology instead of standard morphological evaluation.<ref name=":5" />
Apart from this, there is limited reviewed evidence to support the clinical benefits of morphokinetics and so robust prospective studies reporting clinical outcomes must be carried out before it can be concluded that morphokinetics when combined with time-lapse technology has the ability to improve clinical outcomes of IVF.<ref name=":5" />
== Reference List == <references /> [[Category:Assisted reproductive technology]] [[Category:Childbirth]] [[Category:In vitro fertilisation]]

{{Psychology sidebar}} The '''psychology of eating meat''' is a complex area of study illustrating the confluence of [[morality]], [[emotion]]s, [[cognition]], and [[personality]] characteristics.<ref name=Loughnan2014>{{cite journal|last1=Loughnan|first1=Steve|last2=Bastian|first2=Brock|last3=Haslam|first3=Nick|title=The Psychology of Eating Animals|journal=Current Directions in Psychological Science|date=2014|volume=23|issue=2|pages=104–108|doi=10.1177/0963721414525781|url=https://foodethics.univie.ac.at/fileadmin/user_upload/inst_ethik_wiss_dialog/Loughnan__S._2014_And_Bastian._..The_Psychology_of_Eating_Animals._In._CURRENT_DIRECTIONS_IN_PSYCHOLOGICAL_SCIENCE.pdf|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref> Research into the psychological and cultural factors of [[meat]] eating suggests correlations with [[masculinity]]; support for [[hierarchy|hierarchical]] values; and reduced [[Big Five personality traits#Openness to experience|openness to experience]].<ref name=Rozin2012 >{{cite journal|last1=Rozin|first1=Paul|last2=Hormes|first2=Julia M.|last3=Faith|first3=Myles S.|last4=Wansink|first4=Brian|title=Is Meat Male? A Quantitative Multimethod Framework to Establish Metaphoric Relationships|journal=Journal of Consumer Research|date=October 2012|volume=39|issue=3|doi=10.1086/664970|pages=629–643}}</ref><ref name=Allen2003 /><ref name=Keller2015 /> Because meat eating is widely practiced but is sometimes associated with [[ambivalence]], it has been used as a case study in [[moral psychology]] to illustrate theories of [[cognitive dissonance]] and [[moral disengagement]].{{#tag:ref|[[Paul Rozin|Rozin]] (2004): "Meat should be a subject of special interest to psychologists, because it is a quintessential example of the interesting and important state of ambivalence."<ref name=Rozin2004>[[Paul Rozin|Rozin, Paul]] (2004). "Meat," in Solomon H. Katz (ed.), ''Encyclopedia of Food and Culture'', New York, NY: Scribner, pp. 466–471.</ref>{{paragraph break}}Loughnan et al. (2010): "Amongst omnivores, evaluations of meat are ambivalent, with negative attitudes partially the result of moral concerns regarding the treatment of animals."<ref name="Loughnan2010">{{cite journal | title=The role of meat consumption in the denial of moral status and mind to meat animals | author=Loughnan, Steve| journal=Appetite |year=2010 | volume=55 | issue=1 | pages=156–159 | doi=10.1016/j.appet.2010.05.043 | pmid=20488214|display-authors=etal}}</ref>{{paragraph break}}Graça et al. (2014): "Results indicate that although participants affirmed personal duties towards preserving the environment, promoting public health, and safeguarding animals from harm, they showed patterns that resemble moral disengagement strategies when discussing impacts associated with current meat production and consumption patterns, and the possibility of change— reconstrual of the harmful conduct; obscuring personal responsibility; disregard for the negative consequences; and active avoidance and dissociation."<ref name="Graça2014">{{cite journal|last1=Graça|first1=João|last2=Calheiros|first2=Maria Manuela|last3=Oliveira|first3=Abílio|title=Moral Disengagement in Harmful but Cherished Food Practices? An Exploration into the Case of Meat|journal=Journal of Agricultural and Environmental Ethics|date=Oct 2014|volume=27|issue=5|pages=749–765|doi=10.1007/s10806-014-9488-9|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Joao_Graca/publication/260012288_Moral_Disengagement_in_Harmful_but_Cherished_Food_Practices_An_Exploration_into_the_Case_of_Meat/links/0deec52f0d651b0776000000.pdf|accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref>{{paragraph break}}Loughnan et al. (2014): "The tension omnivores experience when reminded that their behavior may not match their beliefs and values, and the resolution of this tension by changing those beliefs, fits with the theory of cognitive dissonance."<ref name="Loughnan2014" /> |group="n"}} Research into the [[consumer psychology]] of meat is relevant both to [[meat industry]] [[marketing]]<ref name="Richardson Meat Sci">{{cite journal | last=Richardson | first=N.J. | last2=MacFie | first2=H.J.H. | last3=Shepherd | first3=R. | title=Consumer attitudes to meat eating | journal=Meat Science | volume=36 | issue=1-2 | year=1994 | issn=0309-1740 | doi=10.1016/0309-1740(94)90033-7 | pages=57–65}}</ref> and to advocates of reduced [[meat consumption]].<ref name="Klöckner 2014">{{cite journal | last=Zur | first=Ifat | last2=Klöckner | first2=Christian A. | title=Individual motivations for limiting meat consumption | journal=British Food Journal | publisher=Emerald | volume=116 | issue=4 | year=2014 | pages=629–642 | url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1108/BFJ-08-2012-0193 | doi=10.1108/bfj-08-2012-0193 | accessdate=2016-01-03}}</ref><ref name="Schösler">{{cite journal | last=Schösler | first=Hanna | last2=Boer | first2=Joop de | last3=Boersema | first3=Jan J. | title=Can we cut out the meat of the dish? Constructing consumer-oriented pathways towards meat substitution | journal=Appetite | publisher=Elsevier BV | volume=58 | issue=1 | year=2012 | pages=39–47 | url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.appet.2011.09.009 | doi=10.1016/j.appet.2011.09.009 | accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref>
==Consumer psychology== [[File:Man grocery shopping.jpg|thumb|Many factors affect consumer choices about meat, including price, appearance, and source information]]
[[Meat]] is an important and highly [[food choice|preferred]] human [[food]].<ref name="Rozin2012" /> Individuals' attitudes towards meat are of interest to [[consumer psychology|consumer psychologists]], to the [[meat industry]], and to advocates of reduced meat consumption.<ref name=Wyker2010>{{cite journal|last1=Wyker|first1=Brett A.|last2=Davison|first2=Kirsten K.|title=Behavioral Change Theories Can Inform the Prediction of Young Adults' Adoption of a Plant-based Diet|journal=Journal of Nutrition Education and Behavior|date=May 2010|volume=42|issue=3|pages=168–177|doi=10.1016/j.jneb.2009.03.124}}</ref><ref name=Povey2001>{{cite journal|last1=Povey|first1=R.|last2=Wellens|first2=B.|last3=Conner|first3=M.|title=Attitudes towards following meat, vegetarian and vegan diets: an examination of the role of ambivalence|journal=Appetite|date=2001|volume=37|pages=15–26|doi=10.1006/appe.2001.0406|url=http://foodethics.univie.ac.at/fileadmin/user_upload/inst_ethik_wiss_dialog/Povey__R._2001._Attitudes_..._meat__vegetarian__vegan.pdf|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Joyce|first1=Andrew|title=Reducing the Environmental Impact of Dietary Choice: Perspectives from a Behavioural and Social Change Approach|journal=Journal of Environmental and Public Health|date=2012|doi=10.1155/2012/978672|display-authors=etal|volume=2012|pages=1–7}}</ref> These attitudes can be affected by issues of [[price]], [[health]], [[taste]], and [[ethics]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Woodward|first1=Judith|title=Consumer attitudes towards meat and meat products|journal=British Food Journal|date=1988|volume=90|issue=3|pages=101–104|doi=10.1108/eb011814}}</ref><ref name=Worsley1998>{{cite journal|last1=Worsley|first1=Anthony|last2=Skrzypiec|first2=Grace|title=Do attitudes predict red meat consumption among young people?|journal=Ecology of Food and Nutrition|date=1998|volume=32|issue=2|pages=163–195|doi=10.1080/03670244.1998.9991543}}</ref> The perception of meat in relation to these issues affects meat consumption.<ref name="Richardson PNS">{{cite journal | last=Richardson | first=N. J. | title=UK consumer perceptions of meat | journal=Proceedings of the Nutrition Society | volume=53 | issue=02 | year=1994 | issn=0029-6651 | doi=10.1079/pns19940033 | pages=281–287}}</ref><ref name="Font2014" />
Meat is traditionally a high-status food.<ref name="Rozin2012" /> It may be associated with cultural traditions<ref name="CharlesKerr1988" /> and has strong positive associations in most of the world.<ref name="Frank 2007">{{cite journal | last=Frank | first=Joshua | title=Meat as a bad habit: A case for positive feedback in consumption preferences leading to lock-in | journal=Review of Social Economy | publisher=Informa | volume=65 | issue=3 | year=2007 | pages=319–348 | url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00346760701635833 | doi=10.1080/00346760701635833 | accessdate=2016-02-04|quote=Given its historical value and association with privilege, its association with good nutrition and health, and its central position in our diet, it is not surprising that the consumption of meat has strong ingrained positive associations in much of the world.}}</ref> However, it sometimes has a negative image among consumers, partly due to its associations with [[animal slaughter|slaughter]], [[death]], and [[blood]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Guzman, M. A., & Kjaernes, U.|title=Human and animals—a qualitative study.|journal=SIFO report no. 6.|date=1998|publisher=Lysaker, Norway: The National Institute for Consumer Research}}</ref><ref name="Lupton1996">{{cite book|author=Deborah Lupton|title=Food, the Body and the Self|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XoZRsLzddw8C&pg=PA117|date=11 March 1996|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-1-4462-6415-7|pages=117–125}}</ref><ref name="Troy2010">{{cite journal | last=Troy | first=D.J. | last2=Kerry | first2=J.P. | title=Consumer perception and the role of science in the meat industry | journal=Meat Science | publisher=Elsevier | volume=86 | issue=1 | year=2010 | pages=214–226 | url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.meatsci.2010.05.009 | doi=10.1016/j.meatsci.2010.05.009 | accessdate=17 Aug 2015}}</ref> Holding these associations more strongly may decrease feelings of pleasure from eating meat and increase disgust, leading to lowered meat consumption.<ref name=Audebert2006>{{cite journal|last1=Audebert|first1=Olivier|last2=Deiss|first2=Véronique|last3=Rousset|first3=Sylvie|title=Hedonism as a predictor of attitudes of young French women towards meat|journal=Appetite|date=May 2006|volume=46|issue=3|pages=239–247|doi=10.1016/j.appet.2006.01.005|url=http://foodethics.univie.ac.at/fileadmin/user_upload/inst_ethik_wiss_dialog/Audebert__O._2006_Veg_woman_hedonism.pdf|accessdate=10 August 2015}}</ref> In the West, these effects have been found to be particularly true among young women.<ref name="Kubberød2002">{{cite journal|last1=Kubberød, Elin|title=Gender specific preferences and attitudes towards meat|journal=Food Quality and Preference|date=2002|volume=13|issue=5|pages=285–294|doi=10.1016/S0950-3293(02)00041-1|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref name=Kenyon1998>{{cite journal|last1=Kenyon|first1=P.M.|last2=Barker|first2=M.E.|title=Attitudes Towards Meat-eating in Vegetarian and Non-vegetarian Teenage Girls in England—an Ethnographic Approach|journal=Appetite|date=1998|volume=30|pages=185–198|url=http://foodethics.univie.ac.at/fileadmin/user_upload/inst_ethik_wiss_dialog/Kenyon__P._1998_Meat_and_veg_teenage_girls_...pdf|accessdate=10 August 2015|doi=10.1006/appe.1997.0129}}</ref><ref name="Rousset2005">{{cite journal | last=Rousset | first=S. | last2=Deiss | first2=V. | last3=Juillard | first3=E. | last4=Schlich | first4=P. | last5=Droit-Volet | first5=S. | title=Emotions generated by meat and other food products in women | journal=BJN | publisher=Cambridge University Press (CUP) | volume=94 | issue=04 | year=2005 | page=609 | url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1079/BJN20051538 | doi=10.1079/bjn20051538 | accessdate=2016-01-05}}</ref> Negative associations may only cause consumers to make meat less noticeable in their diets rather than reducing or eliminating it, for example making meat an ingredient in a more-processed dish.<ref name="Grunert2006">{{cite journal | last=Grunert | first=Klaus G. | title=Future trends and consumer lifestyles with regard to meat consumption | journal=Meat Science | publisher=Elsevier | volume=74 | issue=1 | year=2006 | pages=149–160 | url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.meatsci.2006.04.016 | doi=10.1016/j.meatsci.2006.04.016 | accessdate=17 Aug 2015}}</ref> It has been suggested that this is the result of a disconnect between individuals' roles as consumers and as citizens.{{#tag:ref|Font-i-Furnols (2014): "Meat and meat products have an important role in many Western and non-Western countries from a social and cultural perspective, and they are a central constituent of our meals and diet despite the overall negative beliefs and attitudes toward them. According to Grunert (2006),<ref name="Grunert2006" /> this apparent contradiction may partially be explained by the distinction between the roles of individuals as consumers and citizens: we may hold a negative attitude toward meat production and consumption as citizens, but it may be weakly displayed in our behavior as consumers."<ref name="Font2014" />|group="n"}}
[[Implicit attitudes]] towards meat have been reported to vary significantly between omnivores and vegetarians, with omnivores holding much more positive views.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=De Houwer|first1=Jan|last2=De Bruycker|first2=Els|title=Implicit attitudes towards meat and vegetables in vegetarians and nonvegetarians|journal=International Journal of Psychology|date=2007|volume=42|issue=3|pages=158–165|doi=10.1080/00207590601067060}}</ref> Vegetarians may express either [[disgust|revulsion]] or [[nostalgia]] at the thought of eating meat.<ref name="Richardson Meat Sci" />{{#tag:ref|A British study found that vegetarians expressed nostalgia specifically for the taste and smell of [[bacon]] with “curious regularity”.<ref name="Richardson Meat Sci" />|group="n"}}
Consumer behavior towards meat may be modeled by distinguishing the effects of ''intrinsic factors'' (properties of the physical product itself, such as color) and ''extrinsic factors'' (everything else, including price and [[brand]]).<ref name="Grunert2006" />
===Intrinsic factors===
Taste and texture are self-reported to be important factors in food choice, although this may not accurately reflect consumer behavior.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shepherd|first1=Richard|chapter=Does Taste Determine Consumption? Understanding the Psychology of Food Choice|title=Food, People and Society|editor1=Frewer, Lynn J.|editor2=Risvik, Einar|editor3=Schifferstein, Hendrik|date=2001|pages=117–130|doi=10.1007/978-3-662-04601-2_8}}</ref> Consumers describe meat as "chewy", "tender", and "rich".<ref name="Kenyon1998" /><ref name=Fiddes>{{cite thesis |last=Fiddes |first=Nick |date=1989 |title=Meat: A Natural Symbol |type=Ph. D. |publisher=University of Edinburgh |url=https://www.era.lib.ed.ac.uk/handle/1842/7171 |access-date=5 August 2015}}</ref> In the [[United Kingdom]], meat is traditionally considered to taste good.<ref name="Richardson PNS" /> People experience the taste and texture of meat in significantly different ways, with variations across ages, genders, and cultures.<ref name="Issanchou1996" /> [[Meat tenderness|Tenderness]] is perhaps the most important of all factors impacting meat eating quality, with others being flavor, juiciness, and succulence.<ref name="Troy2010" />
Visual appearance is one of the primary cues consumers use to assess meat quality at the [[point of sale]], and to select meats. Color is one of the most important characteristics in this context.<ref name="Font2014" /><ref name="Troy2010" /> Different cultural traditions lead consumers to prefer different colors: some countries prefer relatively dark [[pork]] overall, some light, and some have no clear preference.<ref name="Ngapo2007">{{cite journal | last=Ngapo | first=T.M. | last2=Martin | first2=J.-F. | last3=Dransfield | first3=E. | title=International preferences for pork appearance: I. Consumer choices | journal=Food Quality and Preference | publisher=Elsevier | volume=18 | issue=1 | year=2007 | pages=26–36 | url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.foodqual.2005.07.001 | doi=10.1016/j.foodqual.2005.07.001 | accessdate=17 Aug 2015}}</ref>
Visible [[fat]] content and marbling are also important intrinsic quality cues. Consumers as a whole tend to prefer leaner [[beef]] and [[pork]], although significant variations exist across geographical regions. [[Marbled meat|Marbling]] is important to some consumers but not others, and, as for fat content more generally, preference for marbling varies by region.<ref name="Font2014" />
===Extrinsic factors=== Price is an important extrinsic factor which can affect consumer choices about meat.<ref name="Font2011" /> Price concerns may induce consumers to choose among different meats, or avoid meat altogether.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Resurrección|first1=A.V.A.|title=Sensory aspects of consumer choices for meat and meat products|journal=Meat Science|date=2003|volume=66|pages=11–20|doi=10.1016/S0309-1740(03)00021-4|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/AVA_Resurreccion/publication/51777999_Sensory_aspects_of_consumer_choices_for_meat_and_meat_products/links/0046351a7bf742cd43000000.pdf|accessdate=11 August 2015}}</ref>
Health concerns are also relevant to consumer choices about meat.<ref name=Hoek2004>{{cite journal|last1=Hoek|first1=Annet C.|title=Food-related lifestyle and health attitudes of Dutch vegetarians, non-vegetarian consumers of meat substitutes, and meat consumers|journal=Appetite|date=2004|volume=42|pages=265–272|doi=10.1016/j.appet.2003.12.003|url=http://fewd.univie.ac.at/fileadmin/user_upload/inst_ethik_wiss_dialog/Hoek__A._2004_Food-related_lifestyle_.._veget._publ_130_10_2_2005.pdf|accessdate=10 August 2015|display-authors=etal}}</ref> The perceived risk of [[food contamination]] can affect consumer attitudes towards meat, as after meat-related scares such as those associated with [[bovine spongiform encephalopathy|mad cow disease]] or [[avian influenza|bird flu]].<ref name=Font2014>{{cite journal|last1=Font-i-Furnols|first1=Maria|last2=Guerrero|first2=Luis|title=Consumer preference, behavior and perception about meat and meat products: An overview|journal=Meat Science|date=2014|volume=98|pages=361–371|doi=10.1016/j.meatsci.2014.06.025|url=http://www.irta.cat/ca-ES/RIT/Noticies/Documents/Consumer_preference.pdf|accessdate=11 August 2015}}</ref><ref name=Verbeke2004>{{cite journal|last1=Verbeke|first1=Wim|last2=Vackier|first2=Isabelle|title=Profile and effects of consumer involvement in fresh meat|journal=Meat Science|date=2004|volume=67|pages=159–168|doi=10.1016/j.meatsci.2003.09.017|url=http://smas.chemeng.ntua.gr/miram/files../publ_133_10_2_2005.pdf|accessdate=10 August 2015}}</ref> Safety-related product recalls can impact demand for meat.<ref name="Marsh 2004">{{cite journal | last=Marsh | first=Thomas L. | last2=Schroeder | first2=Ted C. | last3=Mintert | first3=James | title=Impacts of meat product recalls on consumer demand in the USA | journal=Applied Economics | publisher=Informa UK | volume=36 | issue=9 | year=2004 | pages=897–909 | url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/0003684042000233113 | doi=10.1080/0003684042000233113 | accessdate=2016-01-06}}</ref> People may reduce or eliminate meat from their diets for perceived health benefits.<ref name="Richardson PNS" /><ref name=Issanchou1996>{{cite journal|last1=Issanchou|first1=S.|title=Consumer expectations and perceptions of meat and meat product quality|journal=Meat Science|date=1996|volume=43|issue=Supplement 1|pages=5–19|doi=10.1016/0309-1740(96)00051-4}}</ref> Health considerations may motivate both meat-eaters and vegetarians.<ref name="Booth1994">{{cite book|author=David Allenby Booth|title=The Psychology of Nutrition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xH2LXR1wiagC&pg=PA78|accessdate=28 August 2015|year=1994|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-7484-0158-1|page=78}}</ref> Meatless diets in adolescents can be a way to conceal [[eating disorders]], although vegetarianism does not necessarily increase the risk of disordered eating.<ref name="Winckel2011">{{cite journal | last=Winckel | first=Myriam Van | last2=Velde | first2=Saskia Vande | last3=Bruyne | first3=Ruth De | last4=Biervliet | first4=Stephanie Van | title=Clinical practice: Vegetarian infant and child nutrition | journal=European Journal of Pediatrics | publisher=Springer Science | volume=170 | issue=12 | year=2011 | pages=1489–1494 | url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00431-011-1547-x | doi=10.1007/s00431-011-1547-x | accessdate=2016-02-04}}</ref>
Research suggests consumers tend to prefer meats whose origin lies in their own country over imported products, partly due to the fact that domestic meats are perceived to be of higher quality.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Dransfield|first1=E.|title=Consumer choice and suggested price for pork as influenced by its appearance, taste and information concerning country of origin and organic pig production|journal=Meat Science|date=2005|volume=69|pages=61–70|doi=10.1016/j.meatsci.2004.06.006|url=http://www.prairieswine.com/pdf/39447.pdf|accessdate=11 August 2015|display-authors=etal}}</ref> This effect may also reflect consumers' [[ethnocentrism]] or [[patriotism]].<ref name=Font2011>{{cite journal|last1=Font-i-Furnols|first1=Maria|title=Consumer’s purchasing intention for lamb meat affected by country of origin, feeding system and meat price: A conjoint study in Spain, France and United Kingdom|journal=Food Quality and Preference|date=2011|volume=22|pages=443–451|doi=10.1016/j.foodqual.2011.02.007|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Maria_Campo/publication/229417374_Consumers_purchasing_intention_for_lamb_meat_affected_by_country_of_origin_feeding_system_and_meat_price_A_conjoint_study_in_Spain_France_and_United_Kingdom/links/0a85e52f232aa7872c000000.pdf|accessdate=10 August 2015|display-authors=etal}}</ref> The importance of meat's country of origin varies from country to country.<ref name="Verbeke2004" /><ref name="Schnettler2009" />
Beliefs and attitudes about [[Environmentalism|environmental]] and [[animal welfare]] concerns can affect meat consumption.<ref name="Richardson Meat Sci" /> Consumers in the developed world may be willing to pay slightly more for meat produced according to higher animal welfare standards, although welfare and environmental concerns are usually considered less important than attributes more directly related to meat quality, such as appearance.<ref name="Grunert2006" /><ref name=Schnettler2009>{{cite journal|last1=Schnettler|first1=Berta|title=Consumer willingness to pay for beef meat in a developing country: The effect of information regarding country of origin, price and animal handling prior to slaughter|journal=Food Quality and Preference|date=2009|volume=20|pages=156–165|doi=10.1016/j.foodqual.2008.07.006|url=http://intranet.uach.cl/dw/canales/repositorio/archivos/28/2824.pdf|accessdate=10 August 2015|display-authors=etal}}</ref> A 2001 study in [[Scotland]] found that, although participants cared about animal welfare in general, they considered price and appearance more important than welfare when buying meat.<ref name=McEachern2002>{{cite journal|last1=McEachern|first1=Morven. G.|last2=Schroder|first2=M. J. A.|title=The Role of Livestock Production Ethics in Consumer Values Towards Meat|journal=Journal of Agricultural and Environmental Ethics|date=2002|volume=15|issue=2|doi=10.1023/A:1015052816477|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Morven_McEachern/publication/225324038_The_Role_of_Livestock_Production_Ethics_in_Consumer_Values_Towards_Meat/links/53f4ab660cf22be01c3ed7dd.pdf|accessdate=10 August 2015|pages=221–237}}</ref> A study of [[Netherlands|Dutch]] consumers found that both rational and emotional responses to environmental and other concerns affected purchasing of [[organic (food)|organic]] meat.<ref name="Verhoef 2005">{{cite journal | last=Verhoef | first=P. C. | title=Explaining purchases of organic meat by Dutch consumers | journal=European Review of Agricultural Economics | publisher=Oxford University Press (OUP) | volume=32 | issue=2 | year=2005 | pages=245–267 | url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1093/eurrag/jbi008 | doi=10.1093/eurrag/jbi008 | accessdate=2015-12-30}}</ref>
Meat consumption patterns can also be influenced by individuals' family, friends, and traditions.<ref name="Richardson Meat Sci" /> A study of British eating patterns found that meat was often associated with positive food traditions, such as the [[Sunday roast]].<ref name="CharlesKerr1988">{{cite book|author1=Nickie Charles|author2=Marion Kerr|title=Women, Food, and Families|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Unq8AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA18|year=1988|publisher=Manchester University Press|isbn=978-0-7190-1874-9}}</ref> Some consumers only purchase meat conforming with religious prescriptions, such as [[halal]] meat. These consumers' trust in quality assurance organizations, and individual relationships with meat providers, have been reported to significantly affect their purchasing behavior.<ref name="Ahmed 2008">{{cite journal | last=Ahmed | first=Allam | title=Marketing of halal meat in the United Kingdom | journal=British Food Journal | publisher=Emerald | volume=110 | issue=7 | year=2008 | pages=655–670 | url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1108/00070700810887149 | doi=10.1108/00070700810887149 | accessdate=2015-12-30}}</ref><ref name="Bonne 2008">{{cite journal | last=Bonne | first=Karijn | last2=Verbeke | first2=Wim | title=Muslim consumer trust in halal meat status and control in Belgium | journal=Meat Science | publisher=Elsevier BV | volume=79 | issue=1 | year=2008 | pages=113–123 | url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.meatsci.2007.08.007 | doi=10.1016/j.meatsci.2007.08.007 | accessdate=2015-12-30}}</ref>
Recent trends in [[animal husbandry]], such as [[biotechnology]], [[factory farming]], and [[animal breeding|breeding]] animals for faster growth, are expected to have a continuing effect on the evolution of consumer attitudes towards meat.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Garnier, Jean-Pierre|title=The potential impact of current animal research on the meat industry and consumer attitudes towards meat|journal=Meat Science|date=2003|volume=63|issue=1|pages=79–88|doi=10.1016/S0309-1740(02)00059-1|url=http://smas.chemeng.ntua.gr/miram/files../publ_129_10_2_2005.pdf|accessdate=10 August 2015|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
==Meat paradox==
One question examined in the psychology of eating meat has been termed the '''meat paradox''': how can individuals care about animals, but also eat them?{{sfn|Loughnan|Bastian|Haslam|2014|p=104|ps=: "This reflects the 'meat paradox': Most people care about animals and do not want to see them harmed but engage in a diet that requires them to be killed and, usually, to suffer."}}{{sfn|Bastian|Crimston|2016|p=280|ps=: "Work in this area has highlighted what is referred to as the meat-paradox: how people can both love animals and enjoy eating meat."}} Internal [[cognitive dissonance|dissonance]] can be created if people's beliefs and emotions about animal treatment do not match their eating behavior, although it may not always be subjectively perceived as a conflict.{{sfn|Loughnan|Bastian|Haslam|2014|pp=104,106}}{{sfn|Blidaru|Opre|2015|pp=548-549|ps=: "A conflict between one’s own eating behaviors, which are dependent on animal suffering and death in factory farms, and one’s cognitions regarding the life rights and welfare of non-human animals, is at the heart of this incongruence."}} This apparent conflict associated with a near-universal dietary practice provides a useful case study for investigating the ways people may change their moral thinking to minimize discomfort associated with ethical conflicts.{{sfn|Loughnan|Bastian|Haslam|2014|pp=106-107}}{{sfn|Bastian|Crimston|2016|p=281}}
Recent studies in this area suggest that people can facilitate their practices of meat eating by attributing lower intelligence and capacity for suffering to meat animals, by thinking of these animals as more dissimilar to humans, by caring less about animal welfare and social inequality, and by dissociating meat products from the animals they come from.{{sfn|Loughnan|Bastian|Haslam|2014|p=106}}{{sfn|Clark|2016|p=465}}
===Perceptions of meat animals=== [[File:Rabbits at Polyface Farm.jpg|thumb|right|Pastured [[Cuniculture|meat rabbits]]. Studies suggest that classifying animals as food can affect their perceived intelligence and moral standing.{{sfn|Bastian|Loughnan|2016|p=4}}{{sfn|Bratanova|Bastian|Loughnan|2011}}{{sfn|Bilewicz|Imhoff|Drogosz|2011}}]] Ethical conflicts arise when eating animals if they are considered to have [[Moral status of animals|moral status]]. Perceptions of animals' moral status vary greatly, but are determined in part by perceptions of [[Animal consciousness|animals as having conscious minds]] and [[Pain in animals|able to experience pain]], and their [[anthropomorphism|perceived similarity to humans]].{{sfn|Loughnan|Bastian|Haslam|2014|p=105}}{{sfn|Waytz|Gray|Epley|Wegner|2010}} Some social psychologists hypothesize that meat eaters can reduce discomfort associated with the meat paradox by minimizing their perception of these morally relevant qualities in animals, particularly animals they regard as food, and several recent studies provide support for this hypothesis.{{sfn|Loughnan|Bastian|Haslam|2014|p=105}}{{sfn|Blidaru|Opre|2015|p=549}}
A 2010 study randomly assigned college students to eat [[beef jerky]] or [[cashews]], then judge the moral importance and cognitive abilities of a variety of animals. Compared with students who were given cashews, those who ate beef jerky expressed less moral concern for animals, and assigned cows a diminished ability to have mental states that entail the capacity to [[Cattle#Cognition|experience suffering]].{{sfn|Loughnan|Bastian|Haslam|2014|p=106}}{{sfn|Loughnan|Haslam|Bastian|2010}}
Subsequent studies similarly found that people were more inclined to feel it was appropriate to kill animals for food when they perceived the animals as having diminished mental capacities,{{sfn|Bastian|Loughnan|Haslam|Radke|2012}} a finding replicated in samples from the [[United States of America|U.S.]], [[Canada]], [[Hong Kong]], and [[India]];{{sfn|Ruby|Heine|2012}} that, conversely, they perceived unfamiliar animals as having lesser mental capacities when told they were used as food;{{sfn|Bratanova|Loughnan|Bastian|2011}} and, again, that eating meat caused participants to ascribe fewer mental abilities to animals over both the short and long term.{{sfn|Bilewicz|Imhoff|Drogosz|2011}}{{sfn|Loughnan|Bastian|Haslam|2014|p=105}}
A 2014 review suggested that these phenomena could be explained as a set of [[cognitive dissonance|dissonance reduction techniques]] used to reduce negative emotions associated with the meat paradox, but noted that the existence of such emotions had not been demonstrated.{{sfn|Loughnan|Haslam|Bastian|2016|p=106}} A 2016 review drew an analogy between the meat paradox and [[sexual objectification]], writing that both practices involve strategically changing perceptions of others when thinking of them as potential "resources" (i.e., for meat or sex), and citing recent studies suggesting that sexually objectifying people prompts a reduction in their perceived humanness and moral importance.{{sfn|Bastian|Crimston|201|6|p=282}}{{sfn|Vaes|Paladino|Puvia|2011}}{{sfn|Loughnan|Haslam|Murnane|Vaes|2010}}
===Dissociation and avoidance=== Several proposed strategies for resolving the meat paradox dissociate meat as a food product from the animals which produce it, or psychologically distance themselves from the processes of meat production.{{sfn|Amiot|Bastian|2016|pp=27-28}} Although concern for animal welfare has recently increased in several countries, a trend towards dissociating meat from its animal origins has tended to prevent such concerns from influencing consumer behavior.{{sfn|Hoogland|de Boer|Boersema|2005}}{{sfn|Perez|de Castro|Font-i-Furnols|2009}}
People in many cultures do not like to be reminded of the connection between animals and meat, and tend to "de-animalize" meat when necessary to reduce feelings of [[guilt (emotion)|guilt]] or of [[disgust]].{{sfn|Vanhonacker|Verbeke|2014|p=161}}{{sfn|Te Velde|Aarts|Van Woerkum|2002}}{{sfn|Kubberød|Ueland|Tronstad|Risvik|2002}} Meat in Western countries is often packaged and served so as to minimize its resemblance to live animals, without eyes, faces, or tails, and the [[market share]] of such products has increased in recent decades;{{sfn|Vanhonacker|Verbeke|2014|p=161}}{{sfn|Eastwood|1995}}{{sfn|Phan-Huy|Fawaz|2003}} however, meat in many other cultures is sold with these body parts.{{sfn|Amiot|Bastian|2016|p=28}}{{sfn|Plous|1993}}
Some authors have suggested that the use of non-animal words such as "[[sirloin]]" and "[[hamburger]]" for meat can reduce the salience of meat's origins in animals, and in turn reduce perceived consumption of animals.{{sfn|Plous|1993}}{{sfn|Rothgerber|2014}} Similarly, farmers and hunters use terms such as "processing" and "managing" rather than "killing", a choice which can be interpreted as a way to provide psychological distance and facilitate animal use.{{sfn|Amiot|Bastian|2016|pp=27-28}}{{sfn|Serpell|1999}}
The importance of dissociation processes was supported by a 2016 Norwegian study which, in a series of experiments, directly tested the effects of making live animals more salient.{{sfn|Kunst|Hohle|2016}}
In addition to dissociation, people who experience discomfort relating to the meat paradox may simply avoid confrontation of the issue. Cultural [[socialization]] mechanisms may also discourage people from thinking of their food choices as harmful; for example, children's books and meat advertisements usually portray farm animals as leading happy lives, or even desiring to be eaten.{{sfn|Plous|1993|p=21}} Compartmentalizing animals in different categories (such as pets, pests, predators, and food animals) may help avoid dissonance associated with differential treatment of different species.{{sfn|Amiot|Bastian|2016|p=31}}{{sfn|Serpell|2009}}
===Pro-meat attitudes=== [[File:Family eating a meal (1).jpg|thumb|right|[[Affective]] factors, such as positive memories, influence meat consumption.]] Ethical conflicts between enjoying meat and caring for animals may be made less problematic by holding positive attitudes towards meat.<ref name="Loughnan2014" /><ref name=Berndsen2004>{{cite journal|last1=Berndsen|first1=Mariëtte|last2=van der Pligt|first2=Joop|title=Ambivalence towards meat|journal=Appetite|date=March 2004|volume=42|pages=71–78|doi=10.1016/S0195-6663(03)00119-3|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Joop_Pligt/publication/8663512_Ambivalence_towards_meat/links/02e7e51cdb3a5b27c7000000.pdf|accessdate=9 August 2015}}</ref> People who think of meat as safe, nutritious, and sustainable tend to experience less ambivalence about eating it.<ref name="Berndsen2004" /> Religious belief in God-given dominion over animals can also justify eating meat.<ref name=Rothgerber2012>{{cite journal| last1=Rothgerber| first1=Hank| title=Real Men Don't Eat (Vegetable) Quiche: Masculinity and the Justification of Meat Consumption| journal=Psychology of Men & Masculinity| date=November 2012| doi=10.1037/a0030379| url=https://foodethics.univie.ac.at/fileadmin/user_upload/p_foodethik/Rothgerber__Hank_2012._Real_Men_Dont_Eat_-Vegetable-__Quiche._Masculinity_and_the_Justification_of_Meat_Consumption.pdf| accessdate=6 August 2015| volume=14| pages=363–375}}</ref>
A series of studies published in 2015 asked meat-eating [[America]]n and [[Australia]]n [[undergraduate]]s to "list three reasons why you think it is OK to eat meat." Over 90% of participants offered reasons which the researchers classified among the "[[Carnism#4 Ns|four N's]]": * Appeals to [[human evolution]] or to [[carnivory]] in nature ("natural") * Appeals to societal or historical [[Norm (social)|norms]] ("normal") * Appeals to nutritive or environmental necessity ("necessary") * Appeals to the tastiness of meat ("nice") The researchers found that these justifications were effective in reducing moral tension associated with the meat paradox.<ref name="Piazza2015">{{cite journal | title=Rationalizing meat consumption. The 4Ns | author=Piazza, Jared | journal=Appetite |date=August 2015 | volume=91 | pages=114–128 | doi=10.1016/j.appet.2015.04.011|display-authors=etal | pmid=25865663}}</ref>
==Personality characteristics==
Studies in [[personality trait]] psychology have suggested that individuals' [[values]] and [[attitude (psychology)|attitudes]] affect the frequency and comfort with which they eat meat.<ref name=Hayley2014>{{cite journal|last1=Hayley|first1=Alexa|last2=Zincklewicz|first2=Lucy|last3=Hardiman|first3=Kate|title=Values, attitudes, and frequency of meat consumption. Predicting meat-reduced diet in Australians|journal=Appetite|date=October 2014|volume=84|pages=98–106|doi=10.1016/j.appet.2014.10.002|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Alexa_Hayley/publication/266944911_Values_attitudes_and_frequency_of_meat_consumption_Predicting_meat-reduced_diet_in_Australians/links/54aa10000cf256bf8bb96222.pdf|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Graça|first=João|last2=Calheiros|first2=Maria Manuela|last3=Oliveira|first3=Abílio|date=2016-02-01|title=Situating moral disengagement: Motivated reasoning in meat consumption and substitution|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0191886915300635|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|volume=90|pages=353–364|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2015.11.042}}</ref>
Those who value [[Theory of Basic Human Values#Self-enhancement|power]] more highly have been found in several studies to eat more meat, while those who prefer [[Theory of Basic Human Values#Self-transcendence|self-transcendence]] values tend to eat less.<ref name="Hayley2014" /> In particular, studies have found that the personality trait of [[Big Five personality traits#Openness to experience|openness to experience]] is negatively correlated with meat consumption, and that vegetarians and [[pescetarianism|pesco-vegetarians]] have more open personalities.<ref name="Keller2015">{{cite journal|last1=Keller|first1=Carmen|last2=Seigrist|first2=Michael|title=Does personality influence eating styles and food choices? Direct and indirect effects|journal=Appetite|date=January 2015|volume=84|pages=128–138|doi=10.1016/j.appet.2014.10.003}}</ref><ref name=Tiainen2013>{{cite journal|last1=Tiainen, A.M.K.|title=Personality and dietary intake. Findings in the Helsinki birth cohort study|journal=PLoS ONE|date=2013|volume=8|issue=7|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0068284|url=http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0068284|accessdate=9 August 2015|display-authors=etal|pages=e68284|pmid=23874573|pmc=3715473}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Forestell, C.A.|title=To eat or not to eat red meat. A closer look at the relationship between restrained eating and vegetarianism in college females|journal=Appetite|date=2012|volume=58|pages=319–325|doi=10.1016/j.appet.2011.10.015|url=http://ac.els-cdn.com/S0195666311006271/1-s2.0-S0195666311006271-main.pdf?_tid=419d8ccc-3ec0-11e5-8d7b-00000aacb35d&acdnat=1439143296_56b84db60597e9a3db70e84670dca672|accessdate=9 August 2015|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mõttus|first1=René|title=Personality Traits and Eating Habits in a Large Sample of Estonians|journal=Health Psychology|date=January 2012|doi=10.1037/a0027041|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Rene_Mttus/publication/221769668_Personality_Traits_and_Eating_Habits_in_a_Large_Sample_of_Estonians/links/0fcfd50f5d9900eff8000000.pdf|accessdate=9 August 2015|display-authors=etal|volume=31|pages=806–814}}</ref>
Other research has indicated that meat consumption is correlated with support for [[hierarchy]] and [[Social inequality|inequality]] values.<ref name="Loughnan2014" /><ref name=Allen2003>{{cite journal|last1=Allen|first1=Michael W.|last2=Ng|first2=Sik Hung|title=Human values, utilitarian benefits and identification: the case of meat|journal=European Journal of Social Psychology|date=January 2003|volume=33|issue=1|doi=10.1002/ejsp.128|pages=37–56}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Wilson |first1=Mark Stuart |last2=Allen |first2=Michael |editor-last=Brown |editor-first=Lois W. |title=Psychology of Motivation |publisher=Nova Science Publishers |date=2007 |pages=65–82 |chapter=Social psychological motivations and foundations of dietary preference |isbn=9781600215988}}</ref> Those with a [[social dominance orientation]], who more strongly support inequality and hierarchical structures, have been found in some studies to eat more meat; it has been suggested that this is consistent with their preference for having certain groups dominate others (in this case, having humans dominate animals).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Dhont|first1=Kristof|last2=Hodson|first2=Gordon|last3=Costello|first3=Kimberly|last4=MacInnis|first4=Cara C.|title=Social dominance orientation connects prejudicial human–human and human–animal relations|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|date=April 2014|volume=61|pages=104–108|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2013.12.020}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Allen|first1=Michael W.|last2=Torres|first2=Claudio V.|title=Food Symbolism and Consumer Choice in Brazil|journal=Latin American Advances in Consumer Research|date=2006|volume=1|url=http://www.acrwebsite.org/volumes/la/v1/laacr_v1_1000062.pdf|accessdate=17 August 2015}}</ref> In addition, research suggests people self-identifying as greater meat eaters have greater [[right-wing authoritarianism]] and social dominance orientation.<ref name="Allen2003"/> Dhont & Hodson (2014) suggested that this subconsciously indicates their acceptance of cultural tradition, and their rejection of nonconformist [[animal rights]] movements.<ref name="Dhont2014a">{{cite journal|last1=Dhont|first1=Kristof|last2=Hodson|first2=Gordon|title=Why do right-wing adherents engage in more animal exploitation and meat consumption?|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|date=2014|volume=64|pages=12–17|url=https://kar.kent.ac.uk/41689/1/Dhont&Hodson%202014%20PAID.pdf|accessdate=6 August 2015|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2014.02.002}}</ref>
Many of these personality characteristics have been shown to relate with moral disengagement in meat consumption. In particular, individuals with higher levels of moral disengagement in meat consumption also tend to show lower levels of general empathy, experience less self-evaluative emotional reactions (i.e. guilt and shame) when considering the impact of meat consumption, endorse group-based discrimination within humans (social dominance orientation), and display power motives of dominance and support of hierarchy of humans over other species (speciesism, human supremacy beliefs). Additionally, they also tend to display higher general propensity to morally disengage, attribute less importance to moral traits in how they view themselves (moral identity), and eat meat more often.<ref name=":0"/>
A detailed study of personality characteristics and diet in [[America]]ns characterized the self-descriptions of increased meat consumers as "pragmatic" and "business- and action-oriented", after correcting for gender differences.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Goldberg|first1=Lewis R.|last2=Strycker|first2=Lisa|title=Personality traits and eating habits: the assessment of food preferences in a large community sample|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|date=2002|volume=32|pages=49–65|url=http://projects.ori.org/lrg/PDFs_papers/Personality-eatinghabits.pdf|accessdate=9 August 2015|doi=10.1016/s0191-8869(01)00005-8}}</ref>
The idea that "you are what you eat", related to superstitions about [[sympathetic magic]] and common in many cultures, may create the perception that eating meat confers animal-like personality attributes.<ref name="NemeroffRozin1989">{{cite journal | last=Nemeroff | first=Carol | last2=Rozin | first2=Paul |title="You Are What You Eat": Applying the Demand‐Free "Impressions" Technique to an Unacknowledged Belief | journal=Ethos | publisher=Wiley-Blackwell | volume=17 | issue=1 | year=1989 | pages=50–69| doi=10.1525/eth.1989.17.1.02a00030 }}</ref>
==Masculinity== [[File:U.S. Marine Corps staff noncommissioned officers with Combat Logistics Company 28, Combat Logistics Regiment 2 prepare meat for their company barbecue at Camp Dwyer in Helmand province, Afghanistan, April 3 130403-M-KS710-022.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Two men in identical short-sleeved shirts and camouflage pants, one very dark-skinned with no hat and one very light-skinned wearing a hat and sunglasses, stand smiling over a barbecue full of cooking meat in a bright location.|In Western traditions and stereotypes, meat [[barbecue]]s have a particularly strong connection with masculinity.{{sfn | Leroy | Praet | 2015 | p=207}}]] In recent years, a considerable amount of [[social psychology]] research has investigated the relevance of meat consumption to perceptions of [[masculinity]].{{sfn | Vartanian | 2015 | p=75}}
The participants in a series of 2012 studies rated mammalian muscle such as steak and hamburgers as more "male" than other foods, and responded more quickly in an [[implicit-association test]] when meat words were paired with typically male names than with female names.{{sfn | Vartanian | 2015 | p=75}}{{sfn | Rozin | Hormes | Faith | Wansink | 2012}} In a different study, perceptions of masculinity among a sample of American undergraduates were positively linked to targets' beef consumption and negatively linked to vegetarianism.{{sfn | Vartanian | 2015 | p=75}}{{sfn | Rothgerber | 2013}} A 2011 Canadian study found that both omnivores and vegetarians perceived vegetarians as less masculine.{{sfn | Loughnan | Bastian | Haslam | 2014 | p=105}}{{sfn | Ruby | Heine | 2011}}
Cultural associations between meat and masculinity are reflected in individuals' attitudes and choices.{{sfn | Ruby | 2012 | p=148}} Across Western societies, women eat significantly less meat than men on average and are more likely to be vegetarian.{{sfn | Ruby | 2012 | p=148 |quote="It is, then, unsurprising that vegetarian women greatly outnumber vegetarian men in Western societies and even among Western non-vegetarians, women eat considerably less meat than men.}}<ref>{{cite book|last1=Arganini|first1=C|last2=Comitato|first2=R|last3=Saba|first3=A|last4=Turrini|first4=A|last5=Virgili|first5=F|editor1-last=Maddock|editor1-first=Jay|title=Public Health - Social and Behavioral Health|date=2012|publisher=INTECH|isbn=978-953-51-0620-3|url=http://www.intechopen.com/books/public-health-social-and-behavioral-health/gender-differences-in-food-choice-and-dietary-intake-in-modern-western-societies|chapter=Gender Differences in Food Choice and Dietary Intake in Modern Western Societies}}</ref> Women are also more likely than men to avoid meat for ethical reasons.{{sfn | Amiot | Bastian | 2015 | p=21}}{{sfn | Ruby | 2012 | p=148}} A 2016 review found that male Germans eat more meat than females, linking the discrepancy to the finding that meat in Western culture has symbolic connections to strength and power, which are associated with male gender roles.{{sfn | Büning-Fesel | Rückert-John | 2016 |pp=2-4}}
Studies have also examined meat eating in the context of attempts to [[impression management|manage others' impressions]] of the eater, finding that men whose masculinity had been challenged chose to eat more meat pizza instead of vegetable pizza.{{sfn | Vartanian | 2015 | p=76}}{{sfn |Lipschitz |2009}} These results indicate that it is possible for dietary choices to influence perceptions of the eater's masculinity or femininity, with meat strongly correlated with perceived masculinity.{{sfn | Vartanian | 2015 | p=79}} It has been suggested that meat consumption makes men feel more masculine, but it remains unclear whether this is the case and how this may be affected by social context.{{sfn | Vartanian | 2015 | p=75}}{{sfn | Rothgerber | 2013}}
==Morality==
In the course of [[human evolution]], the pressures associated with obtaining meat required early [[hominid]]s to [[cooperation|cooperate]] in hunting, and in distributing the spoils afterwards.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rose|first1=Lisa|last2=Marshall|first2=Fiona|title=Meat Eating, Hominid Sociality, and Home Bases Revisited|journal=Current Anthropology|date=April 1996|volume=37|issue=2|pages=307–338|jstor=2744352|doi=10.1086/204494}}</ref><ref name="Stiner Barkai Gopher 2009 pp. 13207–13212">{{cite journal | last=Stiner | first=M. C. | last2=Barkai | first2=R. | last3=Gopher | first3=A. | title=Cooperative hunting and meat sharing 400–200 kya at Qesem Cave, Israel | journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | publisher=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | volume=106 | issue=32 | year=2009 | pages=13207–13212 | url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1073/pnas.0900564106 | doi=10.1073/pnas.0900564106 | accessdate=2015-12-30 | pmid=19666542 | pmc=2726383}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hill|first1=K|title=Altruistic cooperation during foraging by the Ache, and the evolved human predisposition to cooperate|journal=Human Nature—An Interdisciplinary Biosocial Perspective|date=2002|volume=13|issue=1|pages=105–128|doi=10.1007/s12110-002-1016-3}}</ref> In a 2003 paper, psychologist Matteo Marneli proposed that these pressures created the basic principles of human moral judgements: put simply, he argued, "meat made us moral."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mameli|first1=Matteo|title=Meat made us moral: a hypothesis on the nature and evolution of moral judgment|journal=Biology & Philosophy|date=November 2013|volume=28|issue=6|pages=903–931|doi=10.1007/s10539-013-9401-3|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10539-013-9401-3|accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref>
Several studies have found that both omnivores and vegetarians tend to consider vegetarians slightly more moral and virtuous than omnivores.<ref name=Ruby2011>{{cite journal|last1=Ruby|first1=Matthew B.|last2=Heine|first2=Steven J.|title=Meat, morals, and masculinity|journal=Appetite|date=2011|volume=56|issue=2|pages=447–450|doi=10.1016/j.appet.2011.01.018|url=http://foodethics.univie.ac.at/fileadmin/user_upload/p_foodethik/Ruby__M._2011._Meat__morals_and_masculinity.pdf|accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref><ref name=DeBacker2015>{{cite journal|last1=De Backer|first1=Charlotte J.S.|last2=Hudders|first2=Liselot|title=Meat morals: relationship between meat consumption consumer attitudes towards human and animal welfare and moral behavior|journal=Meat Science|date=Jan 2015|volume=99|pages=68–74|doi=10.1016/j.meatsci.2014.08.011|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Charlotte_De_backer/publication/266397294_Meat_morals_relationship_between_meat_consumption_consumer_attitudes_towards_human_and_animal_welfare_and_moral_behavior/links/543408b20cf2bf1f1f27b1d6.pdf|accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref> Ethical principles are often cited among reasons to stop eating meat.<ref name=Santos1997>{{cite journal|last1=Santos-Merx|first1=Lourdes|last2=Booth|first2=David A.|title=Influences on meat avoidance among British students|journal=Appetite|date=1997|volume=27|issue=3|pages=197–205|doi=10.1006/appe.1996.0046|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/14192604_Influences_on_meat_avoidance_among_British_students|accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref><ref name="ShepherdRaats2006">{{cite book|editor1=Richard Shepherd|editor2=Monique Raats|author=Trew, Karen|title=The Psychology of Food Choice|year=2006|publisher=CABI|isbn=978-1-84593-086-8|pages=254–256|chapter=Adolescents, Food Choice, and Vegetarianism|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Some evidence suggests meat-eaters may consider vegetarianism an implicit moral reproach, and respond defensively to vegetarian ideas.<ref name=Minson2012>{{cite journal|last1=Minson|first1=Julia A.|last2=Monin|first2=Benoît|title=Do-Gooder Derogation: Disparaging Morally Motivated Minorities to Defuse Anticipated Reproach|journal=Social Psychological and Personality Science|date=2012|volume=3|issue=2|pages=200–207|doi=10.1177/1948550611415695|url=http://opim.wharton.upenn.edu/DPlab/papers/publishedPapers/Minson_2011_Do-gooder%20derogation.pdf|accessdate=9 August 2015}}</ref>
A 2015 study found that [[Belgium|Belgian]] omnivores, semi-vegetarians ([[flexitarian]]s), and vegetarians have fundamentally different moral outlooks on [[animal welfare]] concerns. However, the three groups were found to donate equally to human-focused charities.<ref name="DeBacker2015" />
Other research has shown how moral disengagement operates in the deactivation of moral self-regulatory processes when considering the impact of meat consumption. In particular, a 2016 study offered an interpretation of moral disengagement as a motivated reasoning process which is triggered by [[loss aversion]] and dissonance avoidance.<ref name=":0" />
Moral perspectives can have a strong influence on meat consumption, but are not uniform across cultures.<ref name="Ruby2013" /><ref name="Rozin1997" /> In the West, choices about meat eating are known to be associated with moral concerns about [[animal welfare]].<ref name="Berndsen2004"/><ref name=Berndsen2005>{{cite journal|last1=Berndsen|first1=Mariëtte|last2=van der Pligt|first2=Joop|title=Risks of meat: the relative impact of cognitive, affective and moral concerns|journal=Appetite|date=April 2005|volume=44|issue=2|doi=10.1016/j.appet.2004.10.003|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0195666304001461|accessdate=8 August 2015|pages=195–205}}</ref> In contrast, the psychology of diet in non-Western cultures has been poorly studied, even though important variations exist from region to region; for example, approximately one third of Indians are vegetarian.<ref name="Ruby2013" /> Research has indicated that, relative to Western vegetarians, Indian vegetarians are more likely to endorse the moral values of [[Ritual purification|purity]], legitimate [[authority]], and respect for [[ingroup]] and [[tradition]].<ref name=Ruby2013>{{cite journal|last1=Ruby|first1=Matthew B.|last2=Heine|first2=Steven J.|last3=Kamble|first3=Shanmukh|last4=Cheng|first4=Tessa K.|last5=Waddar|first5=Mahadevi|title=Compassion and contamination: Cultural differences in vegetarianism|journal=Appetite|date=December 2013|volume=71|issue=1|pages=340–348|doi=10.1016/j.appet.2013.09.004|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0195666313003863|accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref><ref name=Rozin1997>{{cite journal|last1=Rozin|first1=Paul|last2=Markwith|first2=Maureen|last3=Stoess|first3=Caryn|title=Moralization and Becoming a Vegetarian: The Transformation of Preferences Into Values and the Recruitment of Disgust|journal=Psychological Science|date=March 1997|volume=8|issue=2|pages=67–73|url=http://foodethics.univie.ac.at/fileadmin/user_upload/inst_ethik_wiss_dialog/Rozin__.._1997._Moralization_and_becoming_a_vegetarian_in__psychological_science.pdf|accessdate=3 January 2016|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9280.1997.tb00685.x}}</ref>

===Sources=== '''Review articles'''
