(12A)|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/ripd-film-0|work=[[Universal Studios|Universal Pictures Int.]]|publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]]|date=August 12, 2013|accessdate=August 12, 2013}} | country = United States{{cite web |url= http://www.allmovie.com/movie/ripd-v347997 |publisher=[[Allmovie]] |title=R.I.P.D.| last =Wheeler | first = Jeremy|accessdate=May 9, 2013}} | language = English | budget = $130 million{{Cite news|url=https://www.filmla.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/2013-Feature-Production-Report-w-Release-030614_1394125127.pdf|title=2013 Feature Film Study|last=FilmL.A.|first=|date=March 1, 2014|accessdate=July 5, 2017}} | gross = $78.3 million }} '''''R.I.P.D.''''' is a 2013 American [[fantasy film|fantasy]] [[buddy cop]] [[action film|action]] [[comedy film]] starring [[Jeff Bridges]] and [[Ryan Reynolds]]. [[Robert Schwentke]] directed the film based on a screenplay adapted from the comic book ''Rest in Peace Department'' by [[Peter M. Lenkov]]. The film also stars [[Kevin Bacon]], [[Mary-Louise Parker]], [[Stéphanie Szostak]], and [[Marisa Miller]]. Filming was completed on January 28, 2012,{{cite web |url= http://www.flixist.com/ryan-reynolds-r-i-p-d-has-wrapped-filming-206796.phtml |title=Ryan Reynolds: R.I.P.D. has wrapped filming | last = Kubas-Meyer | first = Alec |date=January 30, 2012| publisher=Flixist.com |accessdate=January 30, 2012}} and the film was originally set to be released on June 28, 2013{{cite web |url=http://splashpage.mtv.com/2011/06/27/ripd-release-date |title='R.I.P.D.' Gets A Release Date |last=Marshall |first=Rick |date=June 27, 2011 |publisher=SplashPage.MTV.com |accessdate=July 18, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110630130604/http://splashpage.mtv.com/2011/06/27/ripd-release-date |archivedate=June 30, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} in the United States by [[Universal Studios|Universal Pictures]], but was pushed back to July 19, 2013. The film was both a [[box office bomb|critical and commercial failure]], grossing $78 million on a $130 million budget. ==Plot== [[Boston Police Department]] officers Detective Sergeant Nick Walker and Detective Lieutenant Bobby Hayes discover and steal several shards of gold while on duty. Nick buries his share under an orange tree sapling in his garden; his wife, Julia, thinks that the tree is a surprise gift and mentions how content she is with their life together. Nick realizes that they do not need the gold, and decides to submit it as evidence. During a raid later on Hayes tells Nick that he can't let him turn in the gold, Hayes then shoots and kills Nick. Time stops around Nick and he is drawn into a vortex in the sky. In the afterlife, as [[penance]] for his thievery, Nick is recruited for the R.I.P.D. (The Rest In Peace Department). The R.I.P.D. is responsible for finding and returning souls who refuse to move on to the afterlife. Left unchecked, these souls become "deados", monsters disguised as humans, and when their souls begin to rot, the environment rots around them. He is partnered with Roycephus "Roy" Pulsipher, a former [[U.S. Marshal]] and participant in the [[American Civil War]]. Their first stop is at a cemetery to watch Nick's funeral, and Nick attempts to make his presence known to Julia but is not recognized. Roy explains that R.I.P.D. officers are given new identities and appearances to prevent them from revealing that the afterlife exists. Nick appears as an old Chinese man while Roy appears as a beautiful blonde woman. On his first field mission, Nick aids Roy in interrogating a suspected deado and discovers the perpetrator is in possession of gold like he and Hayes had stolen. Nick and Roy submit the gold as evidence before visiting one of Roy's informants. Nick tricks the informant into revealing Hayes as his contact. They follow Hayes to Nick's old house, where he "discovers" Nick's stolen gold. Roy and Nick track Hayes and observe him handing the gold off to a deado whom they stop and interrogate. The deado overpowers them, taking the gold and transforming into a hulking monster that leads them on a chase through the city that attracts the attention of normal humans and causes a panic. R.I.P.D. Chief Mildred Proctor receives orders to remove Roy and Nick from the case and from active duty due to this exposure. Proctor learns from [[Internal affairs (law enforcement)|Eternal Affairs]] that the gold could be used to construct the Staff of [[Jericho]], which will reverse the flow of souls from earth to the afterlife. Roy and Nick argue, and Nick leaves by himself to try again to reveal himself to Julia. Roy tails him and they argue but finally make amends and decide to work together to stop whatever Hayes is planning. They discover that Hayes is a deado and arrest him, but a confiscated item of his freezes the whole department. Hayes and a group of deados escape with the remainder of the gold and assemble the Staff of Jericho (an [[Obelisk]] of gold). Hayes takes Julia hostage and stabs her as a necessary [[Sacrifice#Human sacrifice|human sacrifice]] to activate the staff. A battle ensues; Pulsipher destroys the Staff of Jericho, and Nick exacts his revenge on Hayes. Close to death, Julia sees Nick for who he is; and they share a tearful farewell. Later, Proctor informs Nick that Julia will live. She reinstates them both fully, though she adds 53 years to Roy's term in the R.I.P.D. due to her revealed affections for him. As a reward, Roy gives Nick a new appearance, but he is dismayed to find it is that of a [[Girl Scout]]. ==Cast== * [[Jeff Bridges]] as Roycephus "Roy" Pulsipher,{{cite web |url=http://deskofbrian.com/2011/05/jeff-bridges-joins-ryan-reynolds-for-r-i-p-d-film |title=Jeff Bridges joins Ryan Reynolds for ‘R.I.P.D’ film | last =Jones | first = Brandon |date=May 28, 2011 |publisher=DeskofBrian.com |accessdate=July 18, 2011}} a [[United States Marshal]] and former [[American Civil War]] [[Yankee]] soldier from the [[American frontier|Wild West]] and veteran officer of the R.I.P.D. * [[Ryan Reynolds]] as Nick Walker,{{cite web |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/movies/news/a212194/ryan-reynolds-joins-ripd-cast.html |title=Ryan Reynolds joins 'R.I.P.D.' cast | last =Armitage | first = Hugh |date=April 2, 2010 |publisher=DigitalSpy.co.uk |accessdate=July 18, 2011}} a detective sergeant of the Boston Police Department who is murdered and becomes Roy Pulsipher's partner. * [[Kevin Bacon]] as Bobby Hayes,{{cite web |url=http://collider.com/kevin-bacon-ripd/106495 |title=Kevin Bacon to Play the Villain in R.I.P.D. Opposite Ryan Reynolds and Jeff Bridges | last =Chitwood | first = Adam |date=July 28, 2011 |publisher=Collider.com |accessdate=September 25, 2011}} a detective lieutenant of the Boston Police Department who is in league with the deados. * [[Mary-Louise Parker]] as Mildred Proctor:{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywood.com/news/Mary_Louise_Parker_in_Talks_to_Join_the_RIPD_Cast/7830654 |title=Mary-Louise Parker Joins Ryan Reynolds in '' | last = Arbeiter | first = Michael |date=February 19, 2011 |publisher=Hollywood.com |accessdate=September 25, 2011}} Head of the Boston Police Department R.I.P.D. * [[Stéphanie Szostak]] as Julia Walker,{{cite web |url=http://scifimafia.com/2011/08/stephanie-szostak-joins-the-cast-of-r-i-p-d |title=Stephanie Szostak Joins the Cast of R.I.P.D. |date=August 11, 2011 |publisher=SciFiMafia.com |accessdate=September 25, 2011}} Nick's wife/widow. * [[Marisa Miller]] as Opal Pavlenko, Roy's avatar.{{cite news |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/marisa-miller-joins-ryan-reynolds-227344 |title=Marisa Miller Joins Ryan Reynolds in 'RIPD' (Exclusive) | last =Kit | first = Borys |date=August 25, 2011 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |accessdate=September 25, 2011}} * [[James Hong]] as Grandpa Jerry Chen, Nick's avatar #1.{{cite web |url=http://www.cinemablend.com/new/James-Hong-And-Mike-O-Malley-Join-The-R-I-P-D-Cast-26436.html |title=James Hong And Mike O'Malley Join The R.I.P.D. Cast | last =Eisenberg | first = Erik |date=August 25, 2011 |publisher=CinemaBlend.com |accessdate=September 25, 2011}} * [[Devin Ratray]] as Pulaski, a Deado * [[Robert Knepper]] as Stanley Nawicki, a Deado. * [[Mike O'Malley]] as Elliot, [[Fenway Park]]'s scoreboard operator. * [[Larry Joe Campbell]] as Officer Murphy * [[Piper Mackenzie Harris]] as Girl Scout, Nick's avatar #2. * [[Toby Huss]], [[Mike Judge]], and Jon Olson as Various Deado Voices [[Zach Galifianakis]] was originally cast as Roy Pulsipher, but dropped out due to scheduling conflicts.{{cite web |url=http://collider.com/zach-galifianakis-r-i-p-d/85144 |title=Zach Galifianakis Drops Out of R.I.P.D. | last = Chitwood | first = Adam |date=April 8, 2011 |publisher=Collider.com |accessdate=September 25, 2011}} [[Jodie Foster]] was originally considered for the role of Proctor, but in the end, [[Mary-Louise Parker]] was cast.{{cite web |url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/archives/mary-louise_parker_takes_role_jodie_foster_was_looking_at_in_r.i.p.d/# |title=Mary-Louise Parker Takes Role Jodie Foster Was Looking At In ‘R.I.P.D.’ |last=Jagernauth |first=Kevin |date=August 19, 2011 |publisher=[[indieWire]] |accessdate=September 25, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006224048/http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/archives/mary-louise_parker_takes_role_jodie_foster_was_looking_at_in_r.i.p.d |archivedate=October 6, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} ==Music== The soundtrack to ''RIPD'' was released on July 16, 2013. {{Track listing | collapsed = no | extra_column = Artist | total_length = 38:58[http://www.theost.com/2013/ripd.html RIPD Soundtrack] TheOST. Retrieved January 4, 2014 | title1 = R.I.P.D. | length1 = 0:58 | extra1 = [[Christophe Beck]] | title2 = The Ascent | length2 = 2:13 | extra2 = Christophe Beck | title3 = Elevator Chase | length3 = 1:58 | extra3 = Christophe Beck | title4 = Orientation | length4 = 2:25 | extra4 = Christophe Beck | title5 = Evidence Room | length5 = 1:25 | extra5 = Christophe Beck | title6 = Partners | length6 = 0:59 | extra6 = Christophe Beck | title7 = Nick's Funeral | length7 = 1:47 | extra7 = Christophe Beck | title8 = A Closer Look | length8 = 2:05 | extra8 = Christophe Beck | title9 = Nawiki | length9 = 1:59 | extra9 = Christophe Beck | title10 = A Powerful Artifact | length10 = 1:59 | extra10 = Christophe Beck | title11 = First Vortex | length11 = 0:39 | extra11 = Christophe Beck | title12 = Fat Elvis | length12 = 1:09 | extra12 = Christophe Beck | title13 = Raining Cars | length13 = 2:19 | extra13 = Christophe Beck | title14 = Hunting Hayes | length14 = 1:22 | extra14 = Christophe Beck | title15 = Track Ghost | length15 = 1:38 | extra15 = Christophe Beck | title16 = High Noon | length16 = 1:14 | extra16 = Christophe Beck | title17 = Half Spheres | length17 = 1:21 | extra17 = Christophe Beck | title18 = House Wrecked | length18 = 1:15 | extra18 = Christophe Beck | title19 = Icy Hot Partner | length19 = 1:10 | extra19 = Christophe Beck | title20 = Mano a Mano | length20 = 1:42 | extra20 = Christophe Beck | title21 = Goodbye | length21 = 1:52 | extra21 = Christophe Beck | title22 = Roy's Hat | length22 = 1:14 | extra22 = Christophe Beck | title23 = The Better Man | length23 = 4:15 | extra23 = [[Jeff Bridges]] }} ==Release== ===Marketing=== On July 16, [[Adult Swim]]'s [[YouTube]] channel uploaded an animated [[prequel]] short, which was produced by [[Titmouse, Inc.]] and featured the voice work of Reynolds and Bridges.{{cite web |url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/news/3243310/adult-swim-airs-sweet-animated-r-i-p-d-prequel/ |title=Adult Swim Airs Sweet Animated ''R.I.P.D.'' Prequel |publisher=''Bloody Disgusting'' |date=July 17, 2013 |accessdate=July 18, 2013}} ===Box office=== The film grossed $12.7 million in its opening weekend, quickly being labeled a [[box office bomb]]. The film ended its theatrical run with $78.3 million worldwide, including a $33.6 million domestic total and $44.7 million in foreign markets.{{cite web | url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=ripd.htm | title=R.I.P.D. (2013) | work=[[Box Office Mojo]] | publisher=[[Internet Movie Database]] | date=September 26, 2013 | accessdate=November 14, 2015}} The film is considered one of the largest box office bombs of all time.https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/22/movies/turbo-and-ripd-open-to-disappointing-results.html?_r=0{{cite news | last= Cohen | first= Sandy | title= 'R.I.P.D.' Box Office Disappoints As 'The Conjuring' Wins The Weekend |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/21/ripd-box-office-disappoints-the-conjuring_n_3631777.html | publisher= Huffington Post | date= July 21, 2013}}http://www.hollywood.com/movies/biggest-box-office-flops-60361701/ ===Critical response=== ''R.I.P.D.'' received generally negative reviews from critics. On [[Rotten Tomatoes]] the film has an approval rating of 14% based on 95 reviews with an average rating of 3.6/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "It has its moments — most of them courtesy of Jeff Bridges' rootin' tootin' performance as an undead Wild West sheriff — but ''R.I.P.D.'' is ultimately too dim-witted and formulaic to satisfy."{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/ripd/ |title=R.I.P.D. (2013) |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango Media]] |accessdate=March 6, 2018}} On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 25 out of 100 based on 27 critics, indicating "generally unfavorable reviews".{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/ripd|title=R.I.P.D. Reviews |work=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=March 6, 2018}} Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "C+" on an A+ to F scale.{{cite web|url=https://m.cinemascore.com |title=CinemaScore |work=cinemascore.com}} Film critic Roger Moore gave the film one-and-a-half out of four stars, calling it "the worst comic book adaptation since ''[[Jonah Hex (film)|Jonah Hex]]''."{{cite web |url=http://rogersmovienation.com/2013/07/19/movie-review-r-i-p-d-is-on-a-par-with-jonah-hex/ |title=Movie Review: ''R.I.P.D.'' – "Jonah Hex Redux" | first = Roger | last = Moore |publisher=''Movie Nation'' |date=July 19, 2013 |accessdate=July 19, 2013}} [[Kyle Smith]] of the ''[[New York Post]]'' gave the film a half-star out of four, writing:
For a movie that so strenuously rips off ''[[Ghostbusters]]'' and ''[[Men in Black (1997 film)|Men in Black]]'', ''R.I.P.D.'' manages to come up with fresh new ways of being absolutely terrible. The plot manages to be fully predictable and freakishly bonkers at the same time, seemingly born of the same kind of brainstorming-on-L.S.D. session that must have given us ''[[Howard the Duck (film)|Howard the Duck]]''.{{cite news |url= http://www.nypost.com/p/entertainment/movies/dead_on_arrival_CKfuMyyEw7dU6wzfgTlv0J |title= ''R.I.P.D.'' Dead on Arrival |last= Smith |first= Kyle |publisher=''[[New York Post]]'' |date= July 18, 2013 |accessdate= July 19, 2013}}
===Video game=== An [[Atlus]] published video game based on the film and titled ''[[R.I.P.D. The Game]]'' was released on July 16, 2013 for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 3]], and [[Xbox 360]]. The game is a [[Cooperative gameplay|co-op]] [[third-person shooter]], set around a [[survival mode]]. It was developed by Old School Games and features gameplay similar to their previous game, ''[[God Mode (video game)|God Mode]]''. Just like its film counterpart, ''R.I.P.D. The Game'' received mostly negative reviews.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/ripd-the-game|title=R.I.P.D. The Game for PC|work=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=July 23, 2013}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0790736|R.I.P.D.}} * {{Mojo title|ripd|R.I.P.D.}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|ripd|R.I.P.D.}} * {{Metacritic film|ripd|R.I.P.D.}} {{Dark Horse Comics films}} {{Robert Schwentke}} {{DEFAULTSORT:R.I.P.D.}} [[Category:2013 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:2013 3D films]] [[Category:2010s action comedy films]] [[Category:2010s supernatural films]] [[Category:American action comedy films]] [[Category:American supernatural films]] [[Category:American buddy films]] [[Category:American buddy cop films]] [[Category:Fictional portrayals of the Boston Police Department]] [[Category:Films scored by Christophe Beck]] [[Category:Films based on Dark Horse Comics]] [[Category:Films directed by Robert Schwentke]] [[Category:Films set in Boston]] [[Category:Films shot in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Films shot in Rhode Island]] [[Category:Films with live action and animation]] [[Category:Films about death]] [[Category:Films about the afterlife]] [[Category:Films about revenge]] [[Category:Live-action films based on comics]] [[Category:Paranormal films]] [[Category:Motion capture in film]] [[Category:Science fantasy films]] [[Category:Dark Horse Entertainment films]] [[Category:Original Film films]] [[Category:Universal Pictures films]] [[Category:Buddy cop films]]

{{Infobox building | name = Rahmat International Wildlife Museum & Gallery | native_name = ''Rahmat Gallery'' | image = Primate Taxidermy, Rahmat International Wildlife Museum and Gallery.jpg | caption = [[Taxidermy]] collection on the museum | groundbreaking_date= | start_date = | completion_date = | inauguration_date = May 14, 1999. | renovation_date = November 28, 2013. | building_type = [[Museum]] | location_town = [[Medan]]
[[North Sumatera]] | location_country = [[Indonesia]] | style= | roof = | top_floor = | antenna_spire = | floor_count = | floor_area = | elevator_count = | architect = | references = | website = http://www.rahmatgallery.com/ }} '''Rahmat International Wildlife Museum & Gallery''' is a [[natural history museum]] in [[Medan]], [[Indonesia]]. The museum displays various collections of wildlife from the smallest to the largest according to the habitat.{{cite web|title=A glimpse of wildlife in Medan museum|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2011/03/30/a-glimpse-wildlife-medan-museum.html|publisher=Jakarta Post|accessdate=8 September 2015|date=March 30, 2011}} After the development was completed in October 2007, the Museum & Gallery has an area of 2970 m² building. Its founder is a fan of [[sport hunting]] and the conservation of nature. Through the museum, he invites visitor to better understand the diversity of wildlife that exist in the world and their importance.[http://www.indonesia-tourism.com/forum/showthread.php?1212-Rahmat-Wildlife-Museum-amp-Gallery-Medan-Indonesia= Tourism page of Indonesia] == Founder == The founder is DR. H. Rahmat Shah, a sports fan and a professional hunting conservationist and nature lover who has traveled around various parts of the world to study directly the concept of conservation that has been adopted by many countries including USA, Canada, Russia, Germany, Turkey, France, Italy, Spain, Austria, China, Kazakhstan, Romania, Mongolia, Iran, Pakistan, Australia, New Zealand, almost all of Africa and other countries in order to prevent extinction and increase wildlife populations and their habitats that remain stable throughout the period.[http://www.rahmatgallery.com/about/=Official site of Rahmat Gallery] == Facility == * Library * Souvenir Shop * Café * Photo Studio * Legend Room == References == {{reflist}} *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0O26NqaaAbs Video of the museum (Indonesian language)] {{coord missing|Indonesia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rahmat International Wildlife Museum and Gallery}} [[Category:Taxidermy]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Medan]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in North Sumatra]] [[Category:Natural history museums in Indonesia]] [[Category:Museums established in 1999]] [[Category:1999 establishments in Indonesia]]

{{Not to be confused with|Stochastic gradient descent#RMSProp}}
'''Rprop''', short for resilient [[backpropagation]], is a learning [[heuristics|heuristic]] for [[supervised learning]] in [[Feedforward neural network|feedforward]] [[artificial neural network]]s. This is a [[First-order approximation|first-order]] [[optimization (mathematics)|optimization]] [[algorithm]]. This algorithm was created by Martin Riedmiller and Heinrich Braun in 1992.<ref>Martin Riedmiller und Heinrich Braun: Rprop - A Fast Adaptive Learning Algorithm. Proceedings of the International Symposium on Computer and Information Science VII, 1992</ref>
Similarly to the [[Manhattan update rule]], Rprop takes into account only the [[Sign (mathematics)|sign]] of the [[partial derivative]] over all patterns (not the magnitude), and acts independently on each "weight". For each weight, if there was a sign change of the partial derivative of the total error function compared to the last iteration, the update value for that weight is multiplied by a factor ''η''<sup>−</sup>, where ''η''<sup>−</sup> < 1. If the last iteration produced the same sign, the update value is multiplied by a factor of ''η''<sup>+</sup>, where ''η''<sup>+</sup> > 1. The update values are calculated for each weight in the above manner, and finally each weight is changed by its own update value, in the opposite direction of that weight's partial derivative, so as to minimise the total error function. ''η''<sup>+</sup> is empirically set to 1.2 and ''η''<sup>−</sup> to 0.5.
Next to the [[cascade correlation algorithm]] and the [[Levenberg–Marquardt algorithm]], Rprop is one of the fastest weight update mechanisms.
RPROP is a batch update algorithm.
==Variations== Martin Riedmiller developed three algorithms, all named RPROP. Igel and Hüsken assigned names to them and added a new variant:<ref name="improving">Christian Igel and Michael Hüsken. [http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/summary?doi=10.1.1.17.1332 Improving the Rprop Learning Algorithm]. Second International Symposium on Neural Computation (NC 2000), pp. 115-121, ICSC Academic Press, 2000</ref> <ref name="evaluation">Christian Igel and Michael Hüsken. [http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?rep=rep1&type=pdf&doi=10.1.1.102.1273 Empirical Evaluation of the Improved Rprop Learning Algorithm]. Neurocomputing 50:105-123, 2003</ref> # RPROP+ is defined at [http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/summary?doi=10.1.1.21.1417 A Direct Adaptive Method for Faster Backpropagation Learning: The RPROP Algorithm].<ref>Martin Riedmiller and Heinrich Braun. [http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/summary?doi=10.1.1.21.1417 A direct adaptive method for faster backpropagation learning: The Rprop algorithm]. Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Neural Networks, 586-591, IEEE Press, 1993</ref> # RPROP− is defined at [http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/summary?doi=10.1.1.27.7876 Advanced Supervised Learning in Multi-layer Perceptrons – From Backpropagation to Adaptive Learning Algorithms]. Backtracking is removed from RPROP+.<ref>Martin Riedmiller. [http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/summary?doi=10.1.1.27.7876 Advanced supervised learning in multi-layer perceptrons - From backpropagation to adaptive learning algorithms]. Computer Standards and Interfaces 16(5), 265-278, 1994</ref> # iRPROP− is defined in [http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/summary?doi=10.1.1.21.3428 Rprop – Description and Implementation Details]<ref>Martin Riedmiller. [http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/summary?doi=10.1.1.21.3428 Rprop – Description and Implementation Details]. Technical report, 1994</ref> and was reinvented by Igel and Hüsken.<ref name=evaluation /> This variant is very popular and most simple. # iRPROP+ is defined at [http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/summary?doi=10.1.1.17.1332 Improving the Rprop Learning Algorithm] and is very robust and typically faster than the other three variants.<ref name="improving"/><ref name="evaluation"/>

'''Ruth L. Ratny''' (c. 1927 – February 21, 2017),<ref name=suntimes>http://chicago.suntimes.com/news/ruth-l-ratny-dies-journalist-covered-chicagos-film-biz/</ref><ref name=chicagoreader >http://www.chicagoreader.com/Bleader/archives/2017/02/23/ruth-ratny-chronicler-of-chicagos-film-industry-dies</ref> born '''Ruth Louise Ratny''',<ref>[http://www.reelchicago.com/article/tribute-legend-ruth-l-ratny170222 A tribute to the legend, Ruth L Ratny]</ref> worked in the Chicago film industry her entire career. As the publisher/editor of [[ReelChicago.com]], an online industry trade publication, she chronicled the Chicago visual media industry for 30 years. She was also a screenwriter of a music biopic about the life and times of [[Mahalia Jackson]], ''The Queen of Soul'', and about what a Mexican woman went through to illegally cross the border.
== Career ==
Prior to ReelChicago, Ratny worked in advertising. Then, in 1979, she founded ''[[Screen Magazine]]'', which she published and edited.<ref name=chicagoreader /> ''Screen'' went beyond a weekly publication, and produced several national trade shows, a score of seminars and the first annual industry networking event.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}}
Health issues compelled Ratny to relinquish her print publication in 2002, but she returned to chronicling the film industry through her ReelChicago.com website in 2004.<ref name=chicagoreader />
In addition to Clios, Emmys, Tells, and Cine Lions, Ratny's honors include induction into Today’s Chicago Woman’s Hall of Fame; Chicago Advertising Woman of the Year, and Midwest Advertising Woman of the Year Awards, and Women in Film’s Recognition Award.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Patton |first1=Daniel |title=A tribute to the legend, Ruth L Ratny |url=https://reelchicago.com/article/tribute-legend-ruth-l-ratny170222/ |accessdate=31 July 2018 |publisher=ReelChicago.com |date=22 February 2017}}</ref>
Ratny received recognition awards from [[Lawyers for the Creative Arts]] and the [[Chicago Coalition]], of which she was a founding member.{{citation needed|date=July 2018}}
== Education ==
Ratny studied marketing at [[DePaul University]], and continued her education at Loyola University. She was active in many local film organizations, and earlier taught courses at [[Columbia College Chicago]]. She also taught selling and marketing for creative services through Screen seminars.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.socialtechpop.com/2010/09/reel-chicago-talks-business/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-08-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110817065424/http://www.socialtechpop.com/2010/09/reel-chicago-talks-business/ |archivedate=2011-08-17 |df= }}</ref>
== Death ==
Ratny died of heart failure at age 89 on February 21, 2017.<ref name=chicagoreader /><ref name=suntimes />
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links ==

{{cleanup|reason=citations need trimming and article needs general cleanup|date=July 2014}} The {{nihongo|"'''Sasebo schoolgirl murder'''"|佐世保女子高生殺害事件|Sasebo Joshikōsei Satsugai jiken}} referred to the [[murder]] of 15-year-old [[Japan]]ese high school student {{nihongo4|Aiwa Matsuo|松尾 愛和|Matsuo Aiwa}} by a 15-year-old female classmate on July 26, 2014. The murder took place in the suspect's apartment in [[Sasebo, Nagasaki|Sasebo]], [[Nagasaki Prefecture]], where Matsuo was beaten with a metal tool, strangled to death, and then partially dismembered and decapitated.<ref name="japantimes2">{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/07/28/national/crime-legal/police-probe-possible-link-online-postings-and-sasebo-killing/ |title=Police probe possible link between 2channel postings and Sasebo killing |publisher=The Japan Times |date= |accessdate=2014-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Shears |first=Richard |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2708150/Schoolgirl-11-beat-female-classmate-death-confessed-slitting-throat-hand-Japan.html |title=Japanese schoolgirl 'beat classmate to death then slit her wrists and throat' | Mail Online |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Molloy |first=Mark |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/japan/10995320/Japanese-schoolgirl-arrested-on-suspicion-of-decapitating-classmate.html |title=Japanese schoolgirl arrested on suspicion of decapitating classmate |publisher=Telegraph |date= |accessdate=2014-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/07/30/national/crime-legal/sasebo-girl-held-slaying-didnt-hold-grudge-victim-police-say/ |title=Sasebo girl held in slaying didn't hold grudge against victim, police say |publisher=The Japan Times |date= |accessdate=2014-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20140729p2a00m0na003000c.html |title=Wake held for schoolgirl murdered in Nagasaki - 毎日新聞 |publisher=Mainichi.jp |date=2013-02-08 |accessdate=2014-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140805221512/http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20140729p2a00m0na003000c.html |archivedate=2014-08-05 |df= }}</ref><ref name="japantimes1">{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/07/31/national/crime-legal/after-grisly-sasebo-killing-teachers-community-wonder-if-there-were-signs/ |title=Sasebo searches for missed signals |publisher=The Japan Times |date= |accessdate=2014-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/08/01/national/crime-legal/psychiatrist-warned-officials-june-sasebo-girl-may-commit-murder/ |title=Psychiatrist warned officials in June that Sasebo girl may commit murder |publisher=The Japan Times |date=2014-08-01 |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20140801p2g00m0dm028000c.html |title=Welfare center received warning in June about teen held for murder - 毎日新聞 |publisher=Mainichi.jp |date=2014-08-01 |accessdate=2014-08-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808053002/http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20140801p2g00m0dm028000c.html |archivedate=2014-08-08 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/01/31/national/media-national/changing-motives-behind-juvenile-crime-japan/|title=The changing motives behind juvenile crime in Japan|work=The Japan Times}}</ref>
==Details== The suspect (15 at the time of the crime, but turned 16 shortly after), whose name has been protected by the police, allegedly posted details and photos of the crime to the popular Japanese message board [[2channel]],<ref name="japantimes2"/> and told police that, "I wanted to kill someone. I bought tools by myself."<ref name="japantimes1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://the-japan-news.com/news/article/0001456161 |title=Teen ‘admits’ killing decapitated classmate |publisher=The Japan News |date= |accessdate=2014-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://the-japan-news.com/news/article/0001458518 |title=16-year-old suspect ‘wanted to try killing someone’ |publisher=The Japan News |date= |accessdate=2014-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/japan/10996952/Japanese-schoolgirl-admits-to-decapitating-classmate.html |title=Japanese schoolgirl admits to decapitating classmate |publisher=Telegraph |date=2014-07-29 |accessdate=2014-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Huffington Post UK |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2014/07/28/japanese-schoolgirl-16-killed-beheaded-classmate-aiwa-matsuo-15_n_5626011.html |title=Japanese Schoolgirl, 16, 'Killed & Beheaded Classmate Aiwa Matsuo, 15' |publisher=Huffingtonpost.co.uk |date=2014-07-27 |accessdate=2014-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Agence France-Presse in Tokyo |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/29/japanese-schoolgirl-beheaded-classmate-reports |title=Schoolgirl 'beheaded classmate because she wanted to dissect someone' | World news |publisher=theguardian.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=McCoy |first=Terrence |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2014/07/30/the-chilling-details-of-a-japanese-teenage-murder-and-decapitation/ |title=The chilling details of a Japanese teenage murder and decapitation |publisher=The Washington Post |date= |accessdate=2014-07-31}}</ref> The suspect had previously attacked her father with a metal baseball bat, prompting him and her step-mother (her biological mother died the previous year) to move her into her own apartment when she began attending high school.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20140731p2a00m0na011000c.html |title=Teenager assaulted father months before killing classmate - 毎日新聞 |publisher=Mainichi.jp |date=2013-02-08 |accessdate=2014-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808052235/http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20140731p2a00m0na011000c.html |archivedate=2014-08-08 |df= }}</ref> It is believed that she first attempted to "dissect" a cat and possessed several medical text books.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20140731p2g00m0dm036000c.html |title=Teen held for friend's killing 'wanted to try dissecting a person' - 毎日新聞 |publisher=Mainichi.jp |date=2013-02-08 |accessdate=2014-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808052242/http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20140731p2g00m0dm036000c.html |archivedate=2014-08-08 |df= }}</ref>
==Response by television broadcasters== In response to the murder, [[Fuji TV]] cancelled the July 31, 2014, broadcast of the fourth episode of the re-edited ''[[Psycho-Pass]]'' anime, which would have also featured murder of teenage schoolgirls.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://topics.jp.msn.com/entertainment/tv/article.aspx?articleid=5275840 |title=佐世保事件と酷似のTVアニメ、放送中止 内容は、女子高生による同級生バラバラ殺人事件だった- 最新ニュース｜MSN トピックス |publisher=Topics.jp.msn.com |date=2014-07-31 |accessdate=2014-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2014/07/31/4th-chapter-of-psycho-pass-new-edit-version-canceled-due-to-similar-murder-case |title=4th Chapter of "Psycho-Pass: New Edit Version" Canceled due to Similar Murder Case |publisher=Crunchyroll |date=2014-07-31 |accessdate=2014-07-31}}</ref>
==Aftermath== The girl's 54-year-old father apologized to Matsuo's family in July 2014 about his daughter's mental health. On October 5, 2014, he was found dead after he committed suicide by hanging.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20141006p2g00m0dm014000c.html|title=Arrested Japanese schoolgirl's father found dead in apparent suicide|work=mainichi.jp|accessdate=6 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141007133057/http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20141006p2g00m0dm014000c.html|archivedate=7 October 2014|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/10/06/national/crime-legal/dad-alleged-schoolgirl-murderer-dies-apparent-suicide-sasebo/|title=Dad of alleged schoolgirl murderer dies in apparent suicide in Sasebo|publisher=|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/09/26/national/crime-legal/arrested-schoolgirls-father-asked-official-not-to-reveal-beating/|title=Father of schoolgirl in Nagasaki slaying asked official not to reveal beating|publisher=|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref>
In 2014, it was revealed that a psychiatrist who examined the girl had contacted a child consultation center in Nagasaki to reportedly warn officials that “If she is left as she is, she could kill someone.”<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/08/01/national/crime-legal/psychiatrist-warned-officials-june-sasebo-girl-may-commit-murder/#.Wn7hd6iWbIU|title=Psychiatrist warned officials in June that Sasebo girl may commit murder}}</ref> However, this warning was not acted upon, and in 2015, three officials of the Nagasaki Prefectural child consultation center were officially reprimanded by the prefectural government, which stated that the center had "failed to fulfill its duties".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/views/vox/AJ201502180030|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218083226/http://ajw.asahi.com/article/views/vox/AJ201502180030|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2015-02-18|title=VOX POPULI: Grisly slayings by teenage girls should give us pause to look within|work=AJW by The Asahi Shimbun}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20150216p2g00m0dm045000c.html |title=Nagasaki Pref. reprimands 3 at child center over murder by girl|accessdate=2015-02-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218093459/http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20150216p2g00m0dm045000c.html |archivedate=2015-02-18 |df= }}</ref>

'''Herbie the skateboarding duck''' (c.1976-83) was the subject of an item first broadcast on the ''[[Midlands Today]]'' insert to the [[BBC]] news magazine programme ''[[Nationwide (TV series)|Nationwide]]'' on 24 May 1978.
Herbie, an [[Aylesbury duck]], was bought by Jacky and Paddy Randall of [[Croydon]] for their children Mikala and Colin. The film, presented by reporter [[Alan Towers]], includes footage of Herbie waddling along the street, joining the family at breakfast and attacking the Randalls' terrier. Part of the film is a four-second shot of Herbie apparently skateboarding by himself on Colin's board. This image seemingly captured the public imagination, and the BBC received many requests for it to be shown again, which it frequently was.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}}
The clip also appeared on other TV stations around the world, many of which also produced their own variations on the theme.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} There was also renewed interest in the clip in 1983 after the death of Herbie was announced{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} and it has been repeated many times since on other TV programmes.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}}
As a result of the item's popularity, the term "skateboarding duck" has come to signify a particular sort of quirky and essentially frivolous news story, often used to fill time at the end of a broadcast.<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/more_sport/article3033257.ece ''Top 50 Greatest Sporting Animals'', timesonline.co.uk, Dec 11, 2007.] accessed Jan 7, 2008</ref>
The item came to define Nationwide in the public mind, and the programme's final item was a sung eulogy to the skateboarding duck, with a surprising twist.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7r4TU9FB6y8 ''Nationwide'', BBC, 5 August 1983.] accessed 7 December 2014</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/shared/spl/hi/newswatch/history/html/default.stm BBC Newswatch] (the full item can be viewed in the 1969 section, this being the year ''Nationwide'' launched).

page.title: Surviving American units with the highest percentage of casualties per conflict

revision.comment: v2.0 - [[WP:WCW]] project (Tag with incorrect syntax - Reference duplication)
revision.text:
{{notability|date=July 2018}} During warfare, circumstances dictate that some units take more casualties than other units. Sometimes the casualty rate is disproportionately high. This article displays the highest percentage of casualties of American units that weren't totally wiped out. The term ''[[Casualty (person)|Casualty]]'' in warfare can often be confusing. It often does not refer to those that are killed on the battlefield; rather, it refers to those who can no longer fight. This can include disabled by injuries, disabled by [[psychological trauma]], [[prisoner of war|captured]], [[desertion|deserted]], or [[missing in action|missing]]. A casualty is just a soldier who is no longer available for the immediate battle or campaign, the major consideration in combat; the number of casualties is simply the number of members of a unit who are not available for duty. For example, during the [[Seven Days Battles]] in the [[American Civil War]] (June 25 to July 1, 1862) there were 5,228 killed, 23,824 wounded and 7,007 missing or taken prisoner for a total of 36,059 casualties.{{harvnb|Tucker|2013|p=892}}{{#tag:ref| Union and Confederate numbers added together|group="A"}} The word ''casualty'' has been used in a military context since at least 1513.Oxford English Dictionary, 2nd ed gives a 1513 reference for military casualty, and an 1844 reference for civilian use ==Battles== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Unit !Conflict !Deployment !Unit size !data-sort-type="number"|KIA !data-sort-type="number"|WIA !data-sort-type="number"|MIA !data-sort-type="number"|POW !data-sort-type="number"|Total !Casualty rate (%) !Opposing force |- |[[1st Minnesota Volunteer Infantry]] |[[Battle of Gettysburg|2nd day of Battle of Gettysburg]] |{{Sort|1863-07-02|July 2, 1863}} |262 | | | 0 | 0 |215 {{harvnb|Holcombe|Searles|1916|p=345}} {{#tag:ref|The 215 casualty figure is disputed. Morning muster on July 2 for the eight companies (A,B,D,E,G,H,I & K) involved in the suicidal attack was 262, and evening muster on the same day was 47. To arrive at the casualty figure of 215, the Regimental Historian (Lt. Wm. Lochren) subtracted the muster figures (262-47=215)(82.1%) and asserted that "[every one of the] 215 [missing men] lay upon the field." Conducting an enumeration by individual names in 1982, Robert W. Meinhard of Winona State University accounted for only 179 (68.3%) casualties for the single day of July 2, 1863. {{harvnb|Maciejewski|2011|p=50}} {{cite journal|last=Meinhard|first=Robert W.|title=Letter to Tom Harrison, Chief Historian, Gettysburg National Military Park|date=20 May 1982}} cited in {{cite book|last=Moe|first=Richard|title=The Last Full Measure: The Life and Death of the First Minnesota Volunteers|year=1993|publisher=Minnesota Historical Society Press|location=St. Paul, MN|isbn=978-087351406-4|pages=275}} Presumably, Meinhard's and Lochren's conclusions are each based upon the same handwritten records from the regiment; accounting for the disputed 36 (=215-179) soldiers is the prerogative of the reader.{{harvnb|Meinhard|1991|p=}}|group="A"}} |82 |{{flagicon|CSA|1863}} Confederacy |- |[[7th Cavalry Regiment]] |[[Battle of the Little Bighorn]] |{{Sort|1876-06-25|June 25–26, 1876}} | 700~ | 268 | 59 | 0 | 0 |327 {{harvnb|Murray|2004|p=113}} | 45~ | Combined [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American Army]]

(191 days at the front) | 3,832 {{#tag:ref|1915 to 1917 infantry regiments grew from 959 to 3,720 men and 112 officers {{harvnb|Woodward|2014|p=108}}|group="A"}} | | | | | 1500 {{sfn|Nelson|2009|pp=203–4}} | 40~ |[[File:Flag of the German Empire.svg|border|25px]] German Empire |- |[[3rd Infantry Division (United States)|3rd Infantry Division]] |[[World War II]] |{{Sort|1942-11-08|Nov 8, 1942-May 8, 1945}}

I. (Return Ira)|last2=Searles|first2= Jasper Newton & Taylor, Mathew F; Colvill Commission | title = History of the First Regiment Minnesota Volunteer Infantry, 1861-1864 : with maps and illustrations|year=1916| publisher = Stillwater, Minn. : Easton & Masterman, printers|oclc=04090632 |url=https://archive.org/stream/04090632.3107.emory.edu/04090632_3107#page/n378/mode/1up}} - Total pages: 508 *{{cite journal |ref=harv|last=Maciejewski|first= Jeffrey|authorlink= |coauthors= |date=July 2011|title=Buying Time|trans_title= |journal= [[America's Civil War]]|volume= |issue= |pages= |id= |url= |quote=|publisher=[[Weider History Group]]|issn=1046-2899}} *{{cite journal |ref=harv|last=Meinhard|first= Robert W |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= July 1991|title=The First Minnesota at Gettysburg : no soldiers ever displayed grander heroism|trans_title= |journal= Gettysburg magazine |volume= vol. 5 |pages=79-88|id= |url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/first-minnesota-at-gettysburg-no-soldiers-ever-displayed-grander-heroism/oclc/32538531&referer=brief_results|accessdate= June 14, 2018 |quote=|publisher= |oclc=32538531}} *{{cite book |ref=harv|last=Murray|first=Stuart | authorlink = | title = Atlas of American Military History|year=2004| publisher = [[Infobase Publishing]]| isbn= 9781438130255 }} - Total pages: 257 * {{cite book|last=Nelson|first=Peter|title=A More Unbending Battle: The Harlem Hellfighter's Struggle for Freedom in WWI and Equality at Home|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z_tPQE1-14YC|date=2009|publisher=Basic Books|isbn=978-0-7867-4467-1|ref=harv}} *{{cite book |ref=harv|last=Tucker|first=Spencer C.| authorlink = Spencer C. Tucker| title = Almanac of American Military History, Volume 1|year=2013| publisher = [[ABC-CLIO]]| isbn= 9781598845303 }} - Total pages: 2524 *{{cite web |ref=harv|last=Walker|first=Mark|date=March 24, 2011|url = http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sdut-military-marine-unit-that-suffered-most-2011mar24-story.html|title =MILITARY: Marine unit that suffered most casualties coming home|publisher = [[The San Diego Union-Tribune]]| accessdate = June 14, 2018 |quote=}} *{{cite book |ref=harv|last=Willbanks|first=James H. | authorlink = | title = Vietnam War Almanac: An In-Depth Guide to the Most Controversial Conflict in American History|year=2013| publisher = [[Skyhorse Publishing|Skyhorse Publishing, Inc]]| isbn= 9781626365285 }} - Total pages: 608 *{{cite book |ref=harv|last=Woodward|first=David | authorlink = David Woodward| title = The American Army and the First World War|year=2014| publisher = [[Cambridge University Press]]| isbn= 9781107011441 }} - Total pages: 465 [[Category:Lists of battles|United States]] [[Category:Lists by death toll|Battles]] [[Category:United States military-related lists|Battles]] [[Category:Battles involving Korea|United States]] [[Category:War casualties|United States]] [[Category:American Civil War-related lists]] [[Category:Battles of the American Civil War]]

'''Thalaikoothal''' ({{lang-ta|தலைக்கூத்தல்}}, lit. showering){{needs-IPA|Tamil}} is the traditional practice of [[senicide]] (killing of the elderly) or [[involuntary euthanasia]], by their own family members, observed in some parts of southern districts of [[Tamil Nadu]] state of [[India]].
==Methods== Typically, the elderly person is given an extensive oil-bath early in the morning and subsequently made to drink glasses of tender [[coconut water]] which results in [[renal failure]], high fever, fits, and death within a day or two.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/chennai/after-thalaikoothal-scare-80-year-old-fights-back-726 |title=After thalaikoothal scare, 80-year-old fights back |date=June 15, 2010 |work=[[Deccan Chronicle]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101118043848/http://www.deccanchronicle.com/chennai/after-thalaikoothal-scare-80-year-old-fights-back-726 |archivedate=November 18, 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.tehelka.com/story_main47.asp?filename=Ne201110Maariyamma.asp|title=Mother, shall I put you to sleep?|volume= 7|issue= 46|date= November 20, 2010|journal=[[Tehelka]]}}</ref> This technique may also involve a head massage with cold water, which may lower body temperature sufficiently to cause heart failure.<ref name="latimes">{{cite news|last= Magnier|first= Mark|url= http://articles.latimes.com/2013/jan/15/world/la-fg-india-mercy-killings-20130116 |title= In southern India, relatives sometimes quietly kill their elders|newspaper= [[Los Angeles Times]]|date= January 15, 2013|accessdate= January 16, 2013}}</ref> Alternative methods involve force feeding cow's milk while plugging the nose, causing breathing difficulties (the "milk therapy") or use of poisons.<ref name="latimes"/>
==Incidence== Although thalaikoothal is illegal in India,<ref name="hi"/> the practice has long received covert social acceptance as a form of mercy killing, and people seldom complain to the police.<ref name=de/> In some case the family informs their relatives before performing thalaikoothal,<ref name=fa/> and the victims sometimes even request it.<ref name="latimes"/> However, social acceptance may lead to more egregious abuses: the issue gained a higher profile in early 2010, when an 80-year-old man escaped when he came to know of his fate and heard his family members discussing how they were going to "share" his lands, and took refuge in a relative's home.<ref name=de/>
Investigation revealed the practice to be "fairly widespread "in the southern districts of Tamil Nadu.<ref name="hi">{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/magazine/article257994.ece|title=No mercy killing, this|date=March 20, 2010|work=The Hindu}}</ref><ref name=de/> Dozens or perhaps hundreds of cases occur each year.<ref name="latimes"/>
==Response== In 2010, after an exposé in [[Virudhunagar district]] the administration set up teams of officers to monitor the senior citizens.<ref name=de>{{cite news|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/chennai/%E2%80%98mercy-killing%E2%80%99-tn-villages-787 |title=‘Mercy killing’ in TN villages |date=January 26, 2010 |work=Deccan Chronicle |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160115045842/http://www.deccanchronicle.com/chennai/%E2%80%98mercy-killing%E2%80%99-tn-villages-787 |archivedate=January 15, 2016 }}</ref><ref name=fa>{{cite news|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/chennai/family-murders-elders-be-probed-801 |title=Family murders of elders to be probed |date=February 2, 2010 |work=Deccan Chronicle, Chennai |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100206014952/http://www.deccanchronicle.com/chennai/family-murders-elders-be-probed-801 |archivedate=February 6, 2010 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} [http://archive.tehelka.com/story_main47.asp?filename=Ne201110Maariyamma.asp Mother, shall I put you to sleep?]
==External links== * [http://palliumindia.org/2010/03/defining-mercy/ Defining Mercy]

{{Expand German|Aufstand des 17. Juni|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox military conflict |conflict=Uprising of 1953 in East Germany |partof=the [[Cold War]] |image=Bundesarchiv Bild 175-14676, Leipzig, Reichsgericht, russischer Panzer.jpg |image_size=300px |caption=A Soviet [[Iosif Stalin tank|IS-2 tank]] in [[Leipzig]] on 17 June 1953 |date=16–17 June 1953 |place=[[East Germany]] |territory= |result=Uprising suppressed |status= |combatants_header= |combatant1=East German demonstrators |combatant2={{flag|Soviet Union|1936}} *{{flagicon image|Red Army flag.svg}} [[Group of Soviet Forces in Germany]] {{flagdeco|Germany}} [[East Germany]] *{{flagicon image|Peoples Police GDR Banner.svg}} [[Volkspolizei]] *{{flagicon image|Sozialistische Einheitspartei Deutschlands Logo.svg}} [[Socialist Unity Party of Germany]] |commander1= |commander2={{flagicon|Soviet Union|1936}} [[Lavrentiy Beria]]
{{flagicon|East Germany|1949}} [[Walter Ulbricht]] |commander3= |units1= |units2= |units3= |strength1= |strength2= |strength3= |casualties1= 55–125 killed http://www.dw.com/en/berlin-commemorates-1953-uprising-in-east-germany/a-39289423 . Retrieved 24 March 2018.
2–4 suicideshttp://www.17juni53.de/tote/recherche.html |casualties2={{flagicon|Soviet Union|1936}} 0–41 killed
{{flagicon|East Germany|1949}} 5 killedhttp://www.17juni53.de/tote/recherche.html |casualties3= 17 deaths unaccounted forhttp://www.17juni53.de/tote/recherche.html |notes= |campaignbox=}} {{Eastern Bloc sidebar}} The '''Uprising of 1953 in East Germany''' started with a [[Strike action|strike]] by [[East Berlin]] [[construction worker]]s on 16 June 1953. It turned into a widespread uprising against the [[East Germany|German Democratic Republic]] government the next day. In Germany, the revolt is often called '''People's Uprising in East Germany''' (''Volksaufstand in der DDR'').{{cite web|url=http://www.bstu.bund.de/DE/Wissen/Publikationen/Publikationen/E_kowalczuk_17-juni-volksaufstand.html|title=BStU - Publikationen der Stasi-Unterlagenbehörde - 17. Juni 1953: Volksaufstand in der DDR|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2014}} It involved more than one million people in about 700 localities.{{cite news|title=60 Years Later, Germany Recalls Its Anti-Soviet Revolt|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/18/world/europe/germany-puts-spotlight-on-its-own-anti-soviet-revolt.html|accessdate=June 18, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=June 17, 2013|author=Alison Smale}} 17 June was a [[public holiday]] in [[West Germany]] up until [[Reunification of Germany|reunification]], and is still a [[anniversary|''Gedenktag'']]. Strikes and working class networks, particularly relating to the old [[Social Democratic Party of Germany]], anti-fascist resistance networks and trade unions played a key role in the unfolding of the uprising. In Soviet history up to the [[Dissolution of the Soviet Union|fall of the Soviet Union]] the uprising was poorly highlighted.''Водопьянова З. К., Филитов А. М.'' Почему Семёнов жалеет патроны? // [[Родина (журнал)|Родина]]. 2002. № 10. С. 109 The uprising in East Berlin was violently suppressed by tanks of the [[Group of Soviet Forces in Germany]] and the ''[[Volkspolizei]]''. In spite of the intervention of [[Soviet troops]], the wave of strikes and [[protest]]s was not easily brought under control. After June 17, there were demonstrations in more than 500 towns and villages. ==Background== {{more citations needed|section|date=June 2018}} In July 1952, the second party conference of the [[Socialist Unity Party of Germany]] (SED) took place in [[East Berlin]]. In SED [[Leadership of East Germany|General Secretary]] [[Walter Ulbricht]]'s words, there was to be the "systematic implementation of Socialism" (''planmäßiger Aufbau des Sozialismus''); it was decided that the process of [[Sovietization]] should be intensified and the importance of the state expanded. The party was acting on decrees made by Soviet premier [[Joseph Stalin]]. This meant for example the division of the five ''[[States of Germany|Länder]]'' into 14 regions (''[[Administrative division of the German Democratic Republic|Bezirke]]'') plus East Berlin. This division was viewed poorly by the remaining middle stratum of the [[East Germany|GDR]]: farmers who owned land and small business owners/tradesmen were being forced to give up their independence through raised charges. This decision was made amid the background of the catastrophic economic situation in the country. In the course of the [[militarisation]] pushed by Soviet authorities, direct and indirect military expenditures rose and already made up around 11% of the national budget in 1952. Together with reparation payments, this totaled over 20% of the budget. The economic policies of the SED favored the development of [[heavy industry]] at the expense of the production of food and consumer goods, all of which resulted in a severe crisis in supplying the public with goods. [[Electricity]] was turned off in factories and public buildings at the onset of darkness every evening (during peak period). The dramatic increase of emigration ([[Republikflucht]], [[brain drain]]) in the first half of 1953, already high since the establishment of the GDR, constituted a serious economic and social problem. Another factor that contributed to an already complicated political situation was the high number of [[political prisoner]]s in the GDR. Suppression of the illegal organisation ''Junge Gemeinde'' (''Young Congregation''), wrongly perceived as the central youth organisation of the [[Lutheran Church|Evangelical Church]], played a role here. Numerous trainee pastors were brutally beaten and imprisoned (e.g. Johannes Hamel and Fritz Hoffmann). Ecclesiastic recreation centres were closed and taken over by the [[Free German Youth|FDJ]] (e.g.: Schloss Mansfeld and Huberhaus Wernigerode). High school students who belonged to a church were often brutally beaten and expelled by the school authorities, sometimes even shortly before school graduation. Within this complicated background, the decision to raise the work norms (in short the principle 'more work for the same salary') was perceived as a provocation, which would conceivably lead to the deterioration of living standards. The Central Committee decided to address the economic difficulties with a package of changes, which included higher taxes and higher prices, and—most significantly—an increase of the work quotas by 10%.Wasserstein, ''Barbarism & Civilization'' page 494. These changes were coming into force by 30 June 1953, Ulbricht's 60th birthday. Issued as a suggestion, it became in effect a direction that was introduced in all the state-owned enterprises (so-called [[Volkseigener Betrieb|''volkseigene Betriebe'']]) and if the new quotas were not met then workers would have to face a reduction of salaries. The decision was taken on 13–14 May 1953, and the [[Council of Ministers of the GDR|Council of Ministers]] approved it on 28 May. Following Stalin's death on March 5, 1953 and the massive increase in emigration, the new Soviet government decided to ease the policies Stalin had demanded. On 4 June 1953, the Soviet government, alarmed at reports of unrest, summoned East German leaders to Moscow. [[Georgy Malenkov]] warned them that if policy direction were not corrected immediately, there would be a catastrophe.Otto Grotewohl's notes on meetings between the leaders 2–4 June 1953; see Ostermann, ''Uprising'' pages 137–138 After intense discussion the East German party eased policies and publicly admitted that mistakes had been made. However, according to the historian of East Germany, Manfred Wilke, that admission may have had the unintended effect of inflaming public opinion rather than easing tensions. ==16 June== [[File:SarahEwart-111.JPG|right|thumb|Former building of the [[Reichsluftfahrtministerium]] (Reich Air Ministry) which then was the site of the House of Ministries. This is the site of the most important memorial to the 1953 Uprising]] On the morning of 16 June, 300 East Berlin construction workers went on strike and marched down Stalinallee, now [[Karl-Marx-Allee]], towards government buildings after their superiors announced a pay cut if they did not meet their work quota. Things started with a discussion by shop stewards as regards how to respond to recent increase in their work quotas. However, this soon turned into a mass demonstration, which gathered more workers from construction sites as they marched first to the headquarters of the [[Free German Trade Union Federation]]. However, dissatisfied with the response there, the protest swelled to over ten thousand as they marched to [[Detlev-Rohwedder-Haus]], the home of the [[Council of Ministers of East Germany|House of Ministries]] in [[Leipziger Strasse]]. They bore banners with such slogans as "We demand a quota reduction!"{{cite web|last1=Dale|first1=Gareth|title=East German rising 17 June 1953|url=https://brunel.academia.edu/garethdale|website=academia.edu|publisher=Jacobin Magazine|accessdate=18 June 2017}} However soon more political demands were developed such as "Workers join us!" "Unity is Strength!" "We want free elections!" and "We want to be free, not slaves." They then demanded that Walter Ulbricht come out to speak to them. When a minor official informed the crowd that their original demand about quotas had been met, this failed to satisfy the protestors who started developing other demands until a young engineer made the suggestion that they put out a call for general strike the next day. These events were reported by the [[West Berlin]]-based [[Radio in the American Sector]] which helped spread news of the intended strike: “The uprising actually began on June 16, 1953, when construction workers in East Berlin marched down what was then Stalinallee to the seat of the Communist government, demanding that it rescind an increase in work hours and calling for a general strike the next day.” RIAS, however, was initially controlled by the U.S. Information Control Division, with the ICD itself as a department of the Office of Military Government, United States (OMGUS). Formed on May 12th, 1945 from the Psychological Warfare Division of SHAEF (PWD/SHAEF), the ICD was led by Robert A. McClure. The PWD itself had its roots in U.S./U.K. intelligence organizations using staff of the US Office of War Information (OWI) and Office of Strategic Services (OSS) and the British Political Warfare Executive (PWE). Also independent networks which had been formed within the old [[Social Democratic Party of Germany]], which had been forcibly merged into the SED, the [[trade unions]] and the [[Union of Persecutees of the Nazi Regime]] – which had recently been dissolved by the authorities - were an element in this self-organisation. ==17 June== [[File:Bundesarchiv B 145 Bild-F005191-0040, Berlin, Aufstand, sowjetischer Panzer.jpg|thumb|250px|A Soviet [[T-34|T-34/85]] tank in East Berlin, 17 June 1953.]] Early on 17 June 40,000 protesters had gathered in East Berlin, with more arriving throughout the morning. Many protests were held throughout [[East Germany]] with at least some work stoppages and protests in virtually all industrial centers and large cities in the country. Joint strike committees were established in [[Hennigsdorf]], [[Görlitz]], [[Cottbus]], and [[Gera]]. The original demands of the protesters, such as the reinstatement of the previous lower work quotas, turned into political demands. [[Socialist Unity Party of Germany|SED]] functionaries took to the streets and began arguing with small groups of protesters. Eventually, the workers demanded the resignation of the East German government. The government decided to violently suppress the uprising and turned to the Soviet Union for military support. In total, around 16 Soviet divisions with 20,000 soldiers as well as 8,000 ''[[Kasernierte Volkspolizei]]'' members were used to quell the uprising. In East Berlin, major clashes occurred along [[Unter den Linden]] (between the [[Brandenburger Tor]] and [[Schloßplatz (Berlin)|Marx-Engels-Platz]]), where Soviet troops and Volkspolizei opened fire,[http://www.17juni53.de/chronik/530617/53-06-17_pdvp-stab.pdf 17juni53.de: Lagebericht NR. 168 des Operativstabes PDVP (in German)], entries 14.32 and 14.42 and around [[Potsdamer Platz]], where several people were killed by the Volkspolizei.victims include Horst Bernhagen, Edgar Krawetzke, Gerhard Schulze, Oskar Pohl, Gerhard Santura: [http://www.17juni53.de/tote/index.html 17juni53.de: Tote des 17. Juni 1953 (in German)] It is still unclear how many people died during the uprising or were sentenced to death in the aftermath. The number of known victims is 55;{{cite web|url=http://www.17juni53.de/tote/recherche.html|title=17juni53.de: Tote des 17. Juni 1953 (in German)|author=DeutschlandRadio Online, Koeln, Germany|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2014}} other estimates put the number of victims at least 125.{{cite web|url=http://www.17juni1953.com/aufstand.html|title=17juni53.'''''com''''': Der Volksaufstand (in German)|author=Tobias Zehnder|date=30 March 2003|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150201222546/http://17juni1953.com/aufstand.html|archivedate=1 February 2015|df=}} Earlier West German estimates of the number of people killed were considerably higher: according to the West German [[Minister of Intra-German Relations|Ministry for Inter-German affairs]] in 1966, 513 people (including 116 "functionaries of the SED regime") were killed in the uprising, 106 people were executed under [[martial law]] or later condemned to death, 1,838 were injured, and 5,100 were arrested (1,200 of these were later sentenced to an average of 5 years in penal camps). It also was alleged that 17 or 18 Soviet soldiers were executed for refusing to shoot demonstrating workers,{{cite web|url=http://www.17juni53.de/tote/recherche.html|title=17juni53.de: Die Opfer des Aufstandes (in German, click on the link)|author=DeutschlandRadio Online, Koeln, Germany|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2014}} but these reports remain unconfirmed by post-1990 research.{{cite web|url=http://www.17juni53.de/tote/magdeburg.html|title=17juni53.de: Vermeintliche und ungeklärte Todesfälle: Bezirk Magdeburg (in German)|author=DeutschlandRadio Online, Koeln, Germany|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2014}} ==Reaction by the East German leadership== On 18 June 1953, ''[[Neues Deutschland]]'', the official party publication of the [[Socialist Unity Party of Germany]] (SED) and the daily national newspaper, published an article on its front page titled "Was ist in Berlin geschehen? (What occurred in Berlin?)" that explained the strike and subsequent uprising to be a direct result of the attempts by "western agencies" to disrupt the national stability and legitimacy of the SED.Neues Deutschland, Do. 18. Juni 1953, Jahrgang 8 Other archived editions of ''Neues Deutschland'' document similar comments made by party officials that condemned the influence of American popular culture on German youth. The prominence of American films and music in both East and West Berlin influenced the rise of a subculture of youth commonly known as [[Halbstarke]] (lit. half-strengths). American films of the era like ''[[The Wild One]]'' and ''[[Rebel Without a Cause]]'', featuring movie stars [[Marlon Brando]] and [[James Dean]], respectively, were viewed by the GDR with romanticizing public disobedience and rebellion, as well as encouraging violent crime. Continued occurrences of crime and uprisings by German youths would eventually lead to the decision by SED party officials to begin construction of the [[Berlin Wall]] in 1961.Poiger, Uta G. Jazz, Rock, and Rebels: Cold War Politics and American Culture in a Divided Germany. Berkeley, CA: U of California, 2000. Print. Page 180 ==Legacy== [[Image:DBPB 1953 110 17.Juni.jpg|thumb|[[Deutsche Bundespost Berlin|West Berlin stamp]] (1953)]] [[Image:DBPB 1953 111 17.Juni.jpg|thumb|West Berlin stamp (1953)]] In memory of the 1953 East German rebellion, [[West Germany]] established 17 June as a [[Public holiday|national holiday]], called "[[Day of German Unity]]". Upon [[German reunification]] in October 1990, it was moved to 3 October, the date of formal reunification. The extension of the [[boulevard]] ''[[Unter den Linden]]'' to the west of the [[Brandenburg Gate]], called ''Charlottenburger Chaussee'', was renamed [[Straße des 17. Juni]] (English: "17 June Street") following the 1953 rebellion. The event is commemorated in the following poem by [[Bertolt Brecht]]: :'''[[Die Lösung|The Solution]]''' :After the uprising of the 17th of June :The Secretary of the Writers Union :Had leaflets distributed in the Stalinallee :Stating that the people :Had forfeited the confidence of the government :And could win it back only :By redoubled efforts. :Would it not be easier :In that case for the government :To dissolve the people :And elect another? Other prominent GDR authors who dealt with the uprising include [[Stefan Heym]] (''Fünf Tage im Juni'' / "Five Days in June", Munich 1974) and [[Heiner Müller]] (''Wolokolamsker Chaussee III: Das Duell'' / "Volokolamsk Highway III: The Duel", 1985/86). West German group [[Alphaville (band)|Alphaville]] mention the date explicitly as "the seventeenth of June" but without reference to the year in their 1984 song "Summer in Berlin," from the album ''[[Forever Young (Alphaville album)|Forever Young]]''. When the compilation album ''[[Alphaville Amiga Compilation]]'' was assembled for release in East Germany in 1988, the song "Summer in Berlin" was submitted for inclusion, but rejected "for political reasons."[http://www.alphaville.info/main.htm Alphaville Discography]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The [[Günter Grass]] play ''{{ill|Die Plebejer proben den Aufstand|de}}'' (''The Plebeians Rehearse the Uprising'') (1966) depicts Brecht preparing a production of [[Shakespeare]]'s ''[[Coriolanus]]'' against the background of the events of 1953. ==See also== *[[Monday demonstrations in East Germany]] *[[Poznań 1956 protests]] *[[Hungarian Revolution of 1956]] *[[Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia]] *[[Tiananmen Square protests of 1989]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * Baring, Arnulf. ''Uprising in East Germany: June 17, 1953'' (Cornell University Press, 1972) * Harman, Chris, Class Struggles in Eastern Europe, 1945-1983 (London, 1988) {{ISBN|0-906224-47-0}} * {{cite book|author=Millington, Richard |title=State, Society and Memories of the Uprising of 17 June 1953 in the GDR|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zVhHBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA172|year=2014|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan}} *{{cite book|author1=Ostermann, Christian F. |author2=Malcolm Byrne|title=Uprising in East Germany, 1953|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j_ci_N3-vAUC&pg=PR35|publisher=Central European University Press}} * Ostermann, Christian F. "" Keeping the Pot Simmering": The United States and the East German Uprising of 1953." ''German Studies Review'' (1996): 61-89. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/1431713 in JSTOR] * Ostermann, Christian F. ''The United States, the East German Uprising of 1953, and the Limits of Rollback'' (Working Paper #11. Cold War International History Project, Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, 1994) [http://www.wilsoncenter.org/sites/default/files/ACFB6C.PDF online] * Richie, Alexandra. ''Faust's Metropolis: a History of Berlin''. New York: Carroll & Graf Publishers, 1998, ch 14 * Sperber, Jonathan. "17 June 1953: Revisiting a German Revolution" ''German History'' (2004) 22#4 pp 619–643. * Tusa, Ann . ''The Last Division: a History of Berlin, 1945-1989''. Reading, Massachusetts: Addison-Wesley, 1997. * Watry, David M. ''Diplomacy at the Brink: Eisenhower, Churchill, and Eden in the Cold War.'' Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 2014. * [[Ilko-Sascha Kowalczuk]]: 17. Juni 1953. Geschichte eines Aufstands. Beck, München 2013. ==External links== *{{Commons category inline|Uprising of 1953 in the German Democratic Republic}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060218033842/http://www.ib.hu-berlin.de/~pbruhn/juni1953.htm Bibliographical Database of the International Literature on the Uprising of June 17, 1953 in the GDR] * Ulrich Mählert. Der 17. Juni 1953, ein Aufstand für Einheit, Recht und Freiheit. Berlin: J.H.W.Dietz, 2003. *[http://libcom.org/history/1953-the-east-german-uprising 1953: The East German uprising] on libcom.org *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/2997736.stm BBC:] Berliner recalls East German uprising (by Ray Furlong) *[https://www.webcitation.org/6FcerDPyL?url=http://www.ib.hu-berlin.de/~pbruhn/juniaugb.htm Der 16. Juni 1953 bleibt mir unvergesslich] Eyewitness report by Peter Bruhn (in German) * Hope M. Harrison. "Driving the Soviets up the Wall: Soviet-East German Relations, 1953-1961." *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080528175652/http://www.volksaufstand-1953.de/english/english.htm June 17, 1953: Personal memories of the strike leader and political prisoner Karl-Heinz Pahling] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20111103065401/http://legacy.wilsoncenter.org/va2/index.cfm?topic_id=1409&fuseaction=home.browse&sort=collection&item=East%20German%20Uprising Cold War International History Project Document Collection on the 1953 East German Uprising] * {{Internet Archive film clip|id=1953_anniversary_of_1953_East_Berlin_uprising|description=1953 anniversary of 1953 East Berlin uprising (1959)}} {{Eastern Bloc}} {{Cold War}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Uprising Of 1953 In East Germany}} [[Category:1953 in Germany]] [[Category:1953 in East Germany]] [[Category:Anti-communism in Germany]] [[Category:Cold War rebellions|East Germany]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1953]] [[Category:1953 riots]] [[Category:1953 protests]] [[Category:Eastern Bloc]] [[Category:Germany–Soviet Union relations]] [[Category:History of East Germany]] [[Category:East Berlin]] [[Category:Foreign relations of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Protests in Germany]] [[Category:Soviet forces in Germany]] [[Category:1953 in international relations]] [[Category:Protest-related deaths|1953]] [[Category:Urban warfare]] [[Category:Rebellions in Germany]] [[Category:Combat incidents]] [[Category:1950s in Berlin]] [[Category:Military operations involving Germany]] [[Category:June 1953 events]] [[Category:Anti-communist resistance movements in Eastern Europe]]

revision.text:
{{For|the album by Jedi Mind Tricks|Violence Begets Violence}} [[File:It Shoots Further Than He Dreams.jpg|alt=|thumb|''It Shoots Further Than He Dreams'' by John F. Knott, March 1918.]] The phrase "'''violence begets violence'''" (or "hate begets hate") means that violent behavior promotes other violent behavior, in return. The phrase has been used since at least the 1830s.{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/11184923/violence_begets_violence_1834/|title="Violence begets violence" (1834)|date=1834-11-04|work=The Times|access-date=2017-05-23|pages=2}} Violence begets violence is a concept described in the [[Gospel of Matthew]], verse 26:52.{{cite web|url=http://www.biblestudytools.com/commentaries/gills-exposition-of-the-bible/matthew-26-52.html|title=Matthew 26:52 Commentary - John Gill's Exposition of the Bible|website=Bible Study Tools}}{{cite web|url=http://www.biblestudytools.com/commentaries/matthew-henry-complete/matthew/26.html|title=Matthew Henry Commentary on the Whole Bible (Complete) |website=www.biblestudytools.com}}{{cite web|url=http://biblehub.com/commentaries/matthew/26-52.htm|title=Matthew 26:52 Commentaries: Then Jesus said to him, "Put your sword back into its place; for all those who take up the sword shall perish by the sword.|website=biblehub.com}} The passage depicts a [[Disciple (Christianity)|disciple]] (identified in the [[Gospel of John]] as [[Saint Peter]]) drawing a sword to defend against the [[arrest of Jesus]] but being told to sheath his weapon:
"Put your sword back in its place," Jesus said to him, "for all who draw the sword will die by the sword."Matthew 26:52, New International Version.
== Words by Martin Luther King Jr. == [[Martin Luther King Jr.]] (1929–1968) used the phrase when saying:{{cite web|url= http://www2.scholastic.com/browse/article.jsp?id=4812|title= Struggle for Equality: Quotes From Martin Luther King, Jr.|website= Scholastic Inc.|date= January 2011|access-date= 2011-01-31|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110122233543/http://www2.scholastic.com/browse/article.jsp?id=4812|archive-date= 2011-01-22|dead-url= yes|df= }}{{cite book|title=Stride Toward Freedom: The Montgomery Story|first1=Martin Luther|last1=King Jr. |authorlink1=Martin Luther King, Jr.|first2=CLayborn|last2=Carson|authorlink2= Clayborne Carson|year=2010 |pages=256 (p. 74)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7JTxjzefViYC&pg=PA74&lpg=PA74}} {{ISBN|0-8070-0069-8}} {{cite web|title=Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Community Celebration - Quotes|website=www.mlk.wsu.edu|date= January 30, 2011|url=http://mlk.wsu.edu/default.asp%3FPageID%3D1481}} {{quote|Hate begets hate; violence begets violence; toughness begets a greater toughness. We must meet the forces of hate with the power of love... Our aim must never be to defeat or humiliate the white man, but to win his friendship and understanding.}} {{quote|The ultimate weakness of violence is that it is a descending spiral begetting the very thing it seeks to destroy, instead of diminishing evil, it multiplies it. Through violence you may murder the liar, but you cannot murder the lie, nor establish the truth. Through violence you may murder the hater, but you do not murder hate. In fact, violence merely increases hate. Returning violence for violence multiplies violence, adding deeper darkness to a night already devoid of stars. Darkness cannot drive out darkness; only light can do that. Hate cannot drive out hate; only love can do that.{{cite book|author=Martin Luther King Jr.|title= Where Do We Go from Here: Chaos or Community?|year=1967|page=67}}}} ==See also== * [[Christian anarchism]] * [[Cycle of violence]] * [[Turning the other cheek]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} [[Category:Peace]] [[Category:Martin Luther King Jr.]] [[Category:Christian nonviolence]] [[Category:Violence]] [[Category:Causality]]

'''Walter de Thornbury''' (died [[1313 in Ireland|1313]]) was an English-born statesman and cleric in 14th century Ireland who held the office of [[Lord Chancellor of Ireland]]. His efforts to secure confirmation of his election as [[Archbishop of Dublin]] were cut short by his death in a [[shipwreck]].
==Biography== Walter de Thornbury was born in [[Herefordshire]], where he was later granted the manor of [[Wolferlow]] by the Mortimer family, with whom he was always closely associated. He was an [[executor]] of the [[will (law)|will]] of [[Edmund Mortimer, 2nd Baron Mortimer]],<ref>Ball F. Elrington ''The Judges in Ireland 1221-1921'' John Murray London 1926</ref> and was appointed guardian to his son [[Roger Mortimer, 1st Earl of March]].<ref>Mortimer, Ian ''The Greatest Traitor- the life of Sir Roger Mortimer, 1st Earl of March'' Jonathan Cape 2003</ref> Given Roger's later role as the [[usurper]], and probably the killer of King [[Edward II]], it is ironic that Walter owed his rise largely to his friendship with the King's favourite [[Piers Gaveston]], who was Roger's co-guardian.<ref>Mortimer </ref> He was much at King Edward's Court in the years 1305-6.<ref>Mortimer</ref>
[[File:Wolferlow Church - geograph.org.uk - 492357.jpg|thumb|A distant view of Wolferlow Church- the manor of Wolferlow was granted to Walter by the Mortimer family c.1300]]
He was sent to Ireland as [[Chancellor of the Exchequer of Ireland]] in 1308 and became [[Lord Chancellor of Ireland]] the following year, on Piers Gaveston's recommendation.<ref>Mortimer ''The Greatest Traitor''</ref> He was deputy [[Treasurer of Ireland]] in 1311, and Treasurer and Chanter of [[St Patrick's Cathedral, Dublin|St. Patrick's Cathedral]]. He accompanied Gaveston on his successful campaign to restore the Crown's authority in [[Leinster]] in 1309, in which he defeated the O'Byrne clan of [[County Wicklow]] and restored order in the neighbourhood of [[Glendalough]].<ref>Otway-Ruthven, A.J. ''History of Medieval Ireland'' Barnes and Noble reissue 1993 p.219</ref> The downfall and execution of his patron Piers Gaveston in June 1312 does not seem to have injured Thornbury's career.
In 1313 he was one of two candidates for the Archbishopric of Dublin, the other being [[Alexander de Bicknor]]. Thornbury, quicker off the mark than his rival, set out for [[Avignon]] to secure [[Papal]] confirmation of his election. The ship sank in a storm with the loss of all lives on board : the dead were reported to have numbered more than 150.<ref>O'Flanagan, J. Roderick ''The Lives of the Lord Chancellors and Keepers of the Great Seal of Ireland'' 2 Volumes London 1870</ref>
==See also== * [[History of Ireland (1169–1536)#Norman decline (1300–1350)]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
